commit_message:
Update sphinx networkx requirements to match g-r

global-requirements excludes sphinx 1.6.7 and caps python 2 since
sphinx 2.0 no longer supports 2.7.

global-requirements caps python 2 since networkx 2.3 no longer supports 2.7.

Change-Id: Ic7f55ea7be42299cabfc4508e7ce36b23312e00d

commit_message:
Don't run bandit during the pep8 tox run

There is already a tox section for bandit which can be executed via
"tox -ebandit". The command in the pep8 section is just a
duplication.

Change-Id: I259a0a4c4dfafb994033e1b15fcfc4022951bf95

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-17 19:19:53.000000000', 'message': 'Fix monasca-grafana being unbuildable due to old npm

Affected builds on Ubuntu which had:
npm 3.5.2
while the latest was:
npm 6.13.4
And CentOS had:
npm 5.6.0

This patch runs npm update via npm.
Pinned to 6.x.

Additionally, this moves npm packages prefix (root) to
/usr/local to avoid conflicts with native packages.

Change-Id: Ibaacc1cc478b2b2f8196a5da4eea3570d7d310ff
Closes-bug: #1856699
(cherry picked from commit 308e85aa413da84ed107b27fa09a3f0e0a64392f)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix monasca-grafana being unbuildable due to old npm

Affected builds on Ubuntu which had:
npm 3.5.2
while the latest was:
npm 6.13.4
And CentOS had:
npm 5.6.0

This patch runs npm update via npm.
Pinned to 6.x.

Additionally, this moves npm packages prefix (root) to
/usr/local to avoid conflicts with native packages.

Change-Id: Ibaacc1cc478b2b2f8196a5da4eea3570d7d310ff
Closes-bug: #1856699
(cherry picked from commit 308e85aa413da84ed107b27fa09a3f0e0a64392f)

commit_message:
Add missing PIP requirements PyMySQL and SQLAlchemy

SQLAlchemy and PyMySQL are missing in requirements.txt/lower-constraints.txt
when osprofiler is isolated from other OpenStack components for instance
installed in Python virtual or in separated container.

Change-Id: I6a8e31177e5adf0a54c2a3ed0b0de18ad0f2ded9
Closes-Bug: #1826646

commit_message:
WIP: Add in-memory key_manager.

The VanillaKeyManager is a in-memory key_manager for development
and testing purposes only. It eliminates the requirement of an
external party such as OpenStack Barbican or HashiCorp Vault
in order to test the KeyManager API.

Change-Id: Ie296b1b195b142ebf9870b1e1ae6a3efc107a8e4
Signed-off-by: Moisés Guimarães de Medeiros <moguimar@redhat.com>

subject: Output api-ref in machine readable format
messages:
[{'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2017-12-18 20:15:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2017-12-18 20:16:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

e.g. in Designate this outputs something like:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/629241/'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2017-12-18 20:19:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

to run this, just change the output format to `yaml` - e.g.:

    sphinx-build -E -W -b yaml -d api-ref/build/doctrees api-ref/source api-ref/build/yaml'}, {'account_id': 6525, 'date': '2018-01-31 02:37:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Graham, this looks promising. Do you have any time to update it? Do you any help?'}, {'account_id': 17556, 'date': '2018-03-15 18:39:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-03-16 14:17:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@melvin it won't pass gate yet - it is still very much a prototype.

@gillies I do, but I need more concrete feedback than promising - suggestions about format or how to show micro versions would be great."}, {'account_id': 6525, 'date': '2018-03-20 03:38:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@graham

A very practical example, currently used by Misty, is https://github.com/flystack/openstack-APIs/blob/master/APIs/nova/v2.1.yaml.

The This is automatically generated from the API Ref/Guides (and webapi although some of those manually because not consistent and yet in the Ref/Guides model). 

It's broken down by resource consisting of a path including parameters when needed, such as "/servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments/{attachment_id}" for example for nova v2.1. 

<RESOURCE>
  <VERB>
    <FUNCTION>[,<FUNCTION>]
  [,<VERB>
    <FUNCTION>[,<FUNCTION>]
  ]

This doesn't cover the data structure when needed (for POST, PUT, etc) which can be passed along as as a second parameter but that could be added latter, this would ultimately allow clients to check an attached structure is valid. 
Also, on the long run, return codes accepted by the each request (VERB) would be a plus but not a blocker for now if added later.

To give a concrete example, as currently used by Misty, such structure allows a client to submit a function, let's say `compute.delete_server(id)` which is translated to a (unique) resource and verb, the resource parameter(s) are expanded which allows to make a DELETE request "/servers/<UUID>" against Nova endpoint.

A function has to be unique, at any point of time (version), which should always be the case. There is only one way of listing servers, and if there are different way then they should have different names (like "delete_servers_batch")
Of course during the evolution of an API, new functions might overwrite existing ones, like fwaas ver fw in neutron for example, but again for that version, the new ones replaces the old one.

Microversions are not explicitly handled here but it doesn't block them either. What need to be done is to formalized the microversion into the structure, which is something that has never been explicitely done by the microversion feature anyway because its a very pragmatic approach as well.
I believe a version tag could be added at the function level if a version signature is needed.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-18 14:37:26.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This appears to have stalled and I'm not sure if anyone is going to have time to work on it. I'm going to abandon this to indicate as such. If someone wants to pick this up, I'm happy to restore it"}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-12-18 14:54:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

yeah, abandoning makes sense - this was a POC spike to show how the output could be done, but the people who were going to take on the work did not materialise'}]

commit_message:
cmd: 'pbr boostrap' create setup.[cfg,py] automatically

PBR-adicted developpers could install pbr user-wide with:

  pip install --user pbr

From then, one would be able to create a setup.py and
setup.cfg with:

  pbr bootstrap

sem-ver: feature

Change-Id: I0a3ff3ad0220a10ac507c8f555651e4fee114c8c
Signed-off-by: Gaetan Semet <gaetan@xeberon.net>

commit_message:
WIP: mock: Fixes missing _autospec key issue

This issue can be encountered when mock.patch is used with
additional kwargs. mock.configure_mock is called before its
_autospec is set.

Change-Id: I388b942b0eb99673adeb5a9073ac2e8f7eb0588f

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-27 14:24:18.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: mock: Makes _AutospecMagicMock a subclass of _AutospecMock

In the mock module, MagicMock is a subclass of Mock, and the autospec
classes should reflect that.

This is needed for a few tests which checks if an object is an instance
of mock.Mock (_AutospecMock if the mock fixture is used), which would
fail if it is a mock.MagicMock instead (_AutospecMagicMock).

Change-Id: I20f4fb465a81ab64c5b26434ba1a3fa63bfd97d8
'}]
commit_message:
WIP: mock: Makes _AutospecMagicMock a subclass of _AutospecMock

In the mock module, MagicMock is a subclass of Mock, and the autospec
classes should reflect that.

This is needed for a few tests which checks if an object is an instance
of mock.Mock (_AutospecMock if the mock fixture is used), which would
fail if it is a mock.MagicMock instead (_AutospecMagicMock).

Change-Id: I20f4fb465a81ab64c5b26434ba1a3fa63bfd97d8

subject: Calculate timestamps within DB
messages:
[{'account_id': 20722, 'date': '2018-08-16 07:54:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20722, 'date': '2018-08-16 08:05:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-08-16 15:11:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

This patch loses the specification of UTC timezone which will have disastrous effects in the usual case of servers that have a timezone configured:


	Python 2.7.15 (default, May 16 2018, 17:50:09) 
	[GCC 8.1.1 20180502 (Red Hat 8.1.1-1)] on linux2
	Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
	>>> from oslo_utils import timeutils
	>>> print(timeutils.utcnow())
	2018-08-16 15:06:14.202839

	[classic@photon2 oslo.utils]$ mysql
	Welcome to the MariaDB monitor.  Commands end with ; or \g.
	Your MariaDB connection id is 47
	Server version: 10.2.16-MariaDB MariaDB Server

	Copyright (c) 2000, 2018, Oracle, MariaDB Corporation Ab and others.

	Type 'help;' or '\h' for help. Type '\c' to clear the current input statement.

	MariaDB [(none)]> select now();
	+---------------------+
	| now()               |
	+---------------------+
	| 2018-08-16 11:06:20 |
	+---------------------+
	1 row in set (0.00 sec)


There are UTC functions which will have to be utilized, however these are backend-specific which means that swiching logic would need to be employed, see http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/core/compiler.html#utc-timestamp-function.

Additionally, I don't know switching to server-side time is worth the risk in general.  The linked bug report does not illustrate any demonstrated issue beyond the hypothetical one raised here.   HA Openstack deployments will make use of multiple databases in a cluster (e.g. Galera) which are local to individual servers in any case, so the problem is not solved at that level either.

As far as clock drift types of issues, the timestamps we put in created_at/ updated_at shouldn't be subject to millisecond-level accuracy demands in any case, servers should make use of ntp to keep drift within 100ms or so.  If they are, then I'd like to see that specific case where we're concerned about this accuracy.

We can of course much more safely make use of database-calculated time as an *option* here, such as if one uses a ServerTimestampMixin, which projects can opt into if they have the need. Once the utc issues above are addressed, this would be much easier to merge since it introduces no new risk.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-18 14:38:52.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-16 07:54:58.000000000', 'message': 'Calculate timestamps within DB

Calculating the timestamp in the clients can lead to problems
because network latency is variable, clients experience slightly
different clock drift.

The SQLAlchemy allows us to do this by passing func.now() which
tells the DB to calculate the timestamp itself.

So, in order to make the updated_at and created_at more accurate,
we should calculate the timestamp in db.

Change-Id: I848035e8e8fe53698cafe1571889d74ec65b64f1
'}, {'created': '2018-08-16 08:05:31.000000000', 'message': 'Calculate timestamps within DB

Calculating the timestamp in the clients can lead to problems
because network latency is variable, clients experience slightly
different clock drift.

The SQLAlchemy allows us to do this by passing func.now() which
tells the DB to calculate the timestamp itself.

So, in order to make the updated_at and created_at more accurate,
we should calculate the timestamp in db.

Closes-bug: #1787345

Change-Id: I848035e8e8fe53698cafe1571889d74ec65b64f1
'}]
commit_message:
Calculate timestamps within DB

Calculating the timestamp in the clients can lead to problems
because network latency is variable, clients experience slightly
different clock drift.

The SQLAlchemy allows us to do this by passing func.now() which
tells the DB to calculate the timestamp itself.

So, in order to make the updated_at and created_at more accurate,
we should calculate the timestamp in db.

Closes-bug: #1787345

Change-Id: I848035e8e8fe53698cafe1571889d74ec65b64f1

commit_message:
Add last finished strategy + fast forward

The existing 'aligned_last_finished' was potentially
over-running earlier by aligning
to the nearest time even if the difference between the
last finish time and the next time was less than
the expected spacing. In order to fix this when this
situation happens we need to shift forward to the
next multiple and use that instead.

So this adds a new strategy that does just that.

Change-Id: Idc065484fe58a2ac419a83fc73228d9305ef15f7

commit_message:
Use spice_agent_enabled key from cloud-compute relation

spice_agent_enabled is provided by nova-cloud-controller to inform
nova-compute the value that needs to be set in the configuration option
[spice].agent_enabled

Change-Id: I49d6e04a545d4b13f9a65e5fd239aa911e75a3ba
Closes-Bug: #1856602

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-13 01:25:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Yeah I think this could stand to be broken up a bit for sanity, just need to spend some time thinking about how to best do that. I've been trying to close out other more straightforward stuff the last couple of weeks but this is on my to-do list to wrap up by the end of next week."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-12-13 01:35:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Yeah I think this could stand to be broken up a bit for sanity,
 > just need to spend some time thinking about how to best do that.
 > I've been trying to close out other more straightforward stuff the
 > last couple of weeks but this is on my to-do list to wrap up by the
 > end of next week.

OK, sweet. Don't feel burdened to break this up yourself, I'm happy to do it if you'd rather focus time on other things. I asked about whether you're OK with that in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698517/1/doc/source/admin/troubleshooting/rebuild-placement-db.rst@20 in case you didn't see.

We've got several customer issues cropped up lately with the various different ways to hit ResourceProviderCreationFailed as a result of a compute node destroy working but an RP delete not working. I need to backport each bug fix to queens and I think breaking each targeted fix into its own patch will help immensely. I expected each piece would have its own func test I expect too to verify each individual way a deployment can get into the "compute node gone but RP failed to delete" state. Again making me think it would be best to break into smaller, more friendly chunks.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-17 15:42:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-17 15:47:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> We've got several customer issues cropped up lately with the various different ways to hit ResourceProviderCreationFailed as a result of a compute node destroy working but an RP delete not working. I need to backport each bug fix to queens and I think breaking each targeted fix into its own patch will help immensely. I expected each piece would have its own func test I expect too to verify each individual way a deployment can get into the "compute node gone but RP failed to delete" state. Again making me think it would be best to break into smaller, more friendly chunks.

Chunking this up isn't as straightforward as it seems as I've noted inline. Reasoning about what works and what doesn't and in what order would be easier with functional tests that recreate the bugs first, so if you want to work on a functional recreate-the-bug type patch then I can work on splitting this apart on top of that to see if it works. As noted inline, simply swapping the order of calls in the compute manager code w/o the report client changes won't fix anything - unit tests would pass and that's why functional tests are needed for this kind of thing, and why I started with recreate functional tests for the bug in question that I'm fixing in the API and resolving FIXMEs in here.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-12-18 03:50:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Chunking this up isn't as straightforward as it seems as I've noted
 > inline. Reasoning about what works and what doesn't and in what
 > order would be easier with functional tests that recreate the bugs
 > first, so if you want to work on a functional recreate-the-bug type
 > patch then I can work on splitting this apart on top of that to see
 > if it works. As noted inline, simply swapping the order of calls in
 > the compute manager code w/o the report client changes won't fix
 > anything - unit tests would pass and that's why functional tests
 > are needed for this kind of thing, and why I started with recreate
 > functional tests for the bug in question that I'm fixing in the API
 > and resolving FIXMEs in here.

Ah, yup, understood about needing report client changes included. Maybe I'm wrong about splitting up this patch. I had been thinking the call ordering bit in the compute manager was a fairly different issue and able to be split out.

Agreed on the need for a recreate-the-bug patch and I've proposed for that:

https://review.opendev.org/699538

I will note that I think the original bug report is wrong and I was not able to reproduce the bug with the steps provided by the bug reporter. However, I did find a way to get the compute service wedged in a different way, which I've written the func test as."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-18 14:14:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Ah, yup, understood about needing report client changes included. Maybe I'm wrong about splitting up this patch. I had been thinking the call ordering bit in the compute manager was a fairly different issue and able to be split out.

Maybe the next steps for this are:

1) rebase on top of your functional test patch https://review.opendev.org/#/c/699538/ to show it fixes the problem

2) flesh the rest of this out without swapping the ordering on the compute delete

3) follow up with a patch that swaps that ordering so it can be reasoned about separately - and maybe that should be a different bug (which would mean you should have a different bug for your func test patch).

--

I think regardless of if/how this is split up, ultimately all pieces go back to queens anyway, like I70e06c607045a1c0842f13069e51fef438012a9c should as well. So getting to something working on master and then figuring out if/how to split up is maybe the way to go, and the answer might be it doesn't make sense to split it or splitting up is unnecessary work."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-22 20:07:48.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Fail compute service delete if resource provider delete fails

Change I7b8622b178d5043ed1556d7bdceaf60f47e5ac80 started deleting
the associated resource provider when a compute service is deleted.
However, the delete_resource_provider cascade=True logic only looks
for instances on the given compute service host being deleted which
will miss (1) allocations remaining from evacuated servers and
(2) unconfirmed migrations.

Attempting to delete the resource provider results in an
ResourceProviderInUse error which delete_resource_provider ignores
for legacy reasons. This results in the compute service being
deleted but the resource provider being orphaned. What's more,
attempting to restart the now-deleted compute service will fail
because nova-compute will try to create a new resource provider
with a new uuid but with the same name (based on the hypervisor
hostname).

This change makes SchedulerReportClient.delete_resource_provider
no longer hide the ResourceProviderInUse/ResourceProviderDeletionFailed
errors and let's them raise up to the caller.

There are two callers of this method, one in the API to delete a compute
service and one in the compute manager to cleanup orphan compute nodes
that are in the DB but no longer reported by the driver (which is mostly
an ironic thing). Both call sites are handled.

In the API, we will return a 409 on ResourceProviderInUse giving the user
some information on things to look for and cleanup before retrying the
delete operation. The related functional test for that is also updated
to show it working. A TODO is left in delete_resource_provider for trying
to detect the evacuate scenario and automatically cleaning up and retrying
the delete. That will be addressed in a later change.

The other call in the ComputeManager is handled but just logged for now.
TBD on what we want to do there once this has had wider review.

Change-Id: Ic634a5957e38beca693304c605d1b6fd36eacc77
Partial-Bug: #1829479
Partial-Bug: #1817833

commit_message:
WIP: Fail compute service delete if resource provider delete fails

Change I7b8622b178d5043ed1556d7bdceaf60f47e5ac80 started deleting
the associated resource provider when a compute service is deleted.
However, the delete_resource_provider cascade=True logic only looks
for instances on the given compute service host being deleted which
will miss (1) allocations remaining from evacuated servers and
(2) unconfirmed migrations.

Attempting to delete the resource provider results in an
ResourceProviderInUse error which delete_resource_provider ignores
for legacy reasons. This results in the compute service being
deleted but the resource provider being orphaned. What's more,
attempting to restart the now-deleted compute service will fail
because nova-compute will try to create a new resource provider
with a new uuid but with the same name (based on the hypervisor
hostname).

This change makes SchedulerReportClient.delete_resource_provider
no longer hide the ResourceProviderInUse/ResourceProviderDeletionFailed
errors and let's them raise up to the caller.

There are two callers of this method, one in the API to delete a compute
service and one in the compute manager to cleanup orphan compute nodes
that are in the DB but no longer reported by the driver (which is mostly
an ironic thing). Both call sites are handled.

In the API, we will return a 409 on ResourceProviderInUse giving the user
some information on things to look for and cleanup before retrying the
delete operation. The related functional test for that is also updated
to show it working. A TODO is left in delete_resource_provider for trying
to detect the evacuate scenario and automatically cleaning up and retrying
the delete. That will be addressed in a later change.

The other call in the ComputeManager is handled but just logged for now.
TBD on what we want to do there once this has had wider review.

TODO: likely also want a release note for the API 409 behavior change

Change-Id: Ic634a5957e38beca693304c605d1b6fd36eacc77
Partial-Bug: #1829479
Partial-Bug: #1817833

- Hide (by renaming) test files that import Neutron code that now
requires Python 3.  We cannot run those test files anymore, until
we (a) figure out how to run them with an older Neutron version,
or (b) fix the networking-calico as a whole to run under Python 3.

- Remove declarations that we support Python 3, as this is actually
not the case.

- Also remove pypy tox environment, as I don't believe we've ever had
any value from it, and other networking-* projects don't have it.

Change-Id: Ib9c5dec59eb5bffad5ce5d9d13be07e513048871
"}]
commit_message:
Minimal changes to maintain CI with Neutron master

- Hide (by renaming) test files that import Neutron code that now
requires Python 3.  We cannot run those test files anymore, until
we (a) figure out how to run them with an older Neutron version,
or (b) fix the networking-calico as a whole to run under Python 3.

- Remove declarations that we support Python 3, as this is actually
not the case.

- Also remove pypy tox environment, as I don't believe we've ever had
any value from it, and other networking-* projects don't have it.

Change-Id: Ib9c5dec59eb5bffad5ce5d9d13be07e513048871

commit_message:
Add autoprogram_cliff_app_dist_name config opt

This allows consumers to let cliff know who they are, so the
autoprogram-sphinx directive doesn't produce messages like

 This command is provided by the $me plugin.

commit_message:
Ceph plugin updates for Luminous

Since the Luminous release of Ceph, the plugin no longer exports metrics
such as object storage daemon stats, placement groups and pool stats.
Check for the installed version of the Ceph command and parse results
according to version.

Include test data for Jewel and Luminous Ceph clusters.

Story: 2005032
Task: 29515

Change-Id: I0aef0db25f49545c715b07880edd57135e3beafe
Co-Authored-By: Bharat Kunwar <bharat@stackhpc.com>
Co-Authored-By: Doug Szumski <doug@stackhpc.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-21 15:27:11.000000000', 'message': "Delete resource providers for all nodes when deleting compute service

Change I7b8622b178d5043ed1556d7bdceaf60f47e5ac80 started deleting the
compute node resource provider associated with a compute node when
deleting a nova-compute service. However, it would only delete the
first compute node associated with the service which means for an
ironic compute service that is managing multiple nodes, the resource
providers were not cleaned up in placement. This fixes the issue by
iterating all the compute nodes and cleaning up their providers.
Note this could be potentially a lot of nodes, but we don't really
have many good options here but to iterate them and clean them up
one at a time.

Note that this is best-effort but because of how the
SchedulerReportClient.delete_resource_provider method ignores
ResourceProviderInUse errors, and we could have stale allocations
on the host for which delete_resource_provider is not accounting,
namely allocations from evacuated instances (or incomplete migrations
though you can't migrate baremetal instances today), we could still
delete the compute service and orphan those in-use providers. That,
however, is no worse than before this change where we did not try
to cleanup all providers. The issue described above is being tracked
with bug 1829479 and will be dealt with separately.

Change-Id: I9e852e25ea89f32bf19cdaeb1f5dac8f749f5dbc
Closes-Bug: #1811726
(cherry picked from commit 650fe118d128f09f78552b82abc114bb4b84930e)
(cherry picked from commit e9889be94ee58a6da78ef96d09d8f5282b86f648)
(cherry picked from commit 64d52788831f0e676f0b9bf9780eeadb38232def)
(cherry picked from commit b2f438bab4a0fdaa37b1a57cff0b27fb2a3f3437)
"}]
commit_message:
Delete resource providers for all nodes when deleting compute service

Change I7b8622b178d5043ed1556d7bdceaf60f47e5ac80 started deleting the
compute node resource provider associated with a compute node when
deleting a nova-compute service. However, it would only delete the
first compute node associated with the service which means for an
ironic compute service that is managing multiple nodes, the resource
providers were not cleaned up in placement. This fixes the issue by
iterating all the compute nodes and cleaning up their providers.
Note this could be potentially a lot of nodes, but we don't really
have many good options here but to iterate them and clean them up
one at a time.

Note that this is best-effort but because of how the
SchedulerReportClient.delete_resource_provider method ignores
ResourceProviderInUse errors, and we could have stale allocations
on the host for which delete_resource_provider is not accounting,
namely allocations from evacuated instances (or incomplete migrations
though you can't migrate baremetal instances today), we could still
delete the compute service and orphan those in-use providers. That,
however, is no worse than before this change where we did not try
to cleanup all providers. The issue described above is being tracked
with bug 1829479 and will be dealt with separately.

Change-Id: I9e852e25ea89f32bf19cdaeb1f5dac8f749f5dbc
Closes-Bug: #1811726
(cherry picked from commit 650fe118d128f09f78552b82abc114bb4b84930e)
(cherry picked from commit e9889be94ee58a6da78ef96d09d8f5282b86f648)
(cherry picked from commit 64d52788831f0e676f0b9bf9780eeadb38232def)
(cherry picked from commit b2f438bab4a0fdaa37b1a57cff0b27fb2a3f3437)

commit_message:
Remove py2 testing, jobs

Change tox.ini so that all jobs are python3, and add explicit
unit/functional testenvs for the two ussuri python runtimes
(3.6 and 3.7).

Remove py2 jobs from .zuul.yaml and redefine the periodic "tips"
jobs so that they are testing with the ussuri python runtimes.
Added nodeset: ubuntu-bionic to the abstract base jobs so that
py3.7 is available.

Co-authored-by: Ghanshyam Mann <gmann@ghanshyammann.com>
Co-authored-by: Brian Rosmaita <rosmaita.fossdev@gmail.com>

Closes-bug: #1853693
Change-Id: I15467c34fc8466fa1724c5401dc879ae77c1922d

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-19 13:18:30.000000000', 'message': 'Exclude build request marker from server listing

When listing "real" (already in cell) instances e.g. from
nova_cell1.instances table, a marker option means "start after the
instance with marker".

For VMs:

| uuid | name |
| 1    | vm1  |
| 2    | vm2  |

"openstack server list --marker 1" returns vm2 only.

But for VMs from nova_api.build_requests table it's different.

For VMs:

| uuid | name |
| 1    | vm1  |
| 2    | vm2  |

"openstack server list --marker 1" returns both vm1 and vm2.

This patch excludes instance with marker from listing for
instances from build_requests table.

Closes-Bug: #1808286
Change-Id: I5165b69f956fbf1904112a742698b2739f747e72
(cherry picked from commit 2ef704cba619a149336692311c2614742aa32909)
(cherry picked from commit 3eb0ba988f4cfca4399c92cd6bb7b4ae8665720c)
(cherry picked from commit 8aadd4ebdfea3f1b46b2e2e62b355e8b40b6261b)
(cherry picked from commit 3d3a263789c5cc49899d63d18f9233c981f5b894)
'}]
commit_message:
Exclude build request marker from server listing

When listing "real" (already in cell) instances e.g. from
nova_cell1.instances table, a marker option means "start after the
instance with marker".

For VMs:

| uuid | name |
| 1    | vm1  |
| 2    | vm2  |

"openstack server list --marker 1" returns vm2 only.

But for VMs from nova_api.build_requests table it's different.

For VMs:

| uuid | name |
| 1    | vm1  |
| 2    | vm2  |

"openstack server list --marker 1" returns both vm1 and vm2.

This patch excludes instance with marker from listing for
instances from build_requests table.

Closes-Bug: #1808286
Change-Id: I5165b69f956fbf1904112a742698b2739f747e72
(cherry picked from commit 2ef704cba619a149336692311c2614742aa32909)
(cherry picked from commit 3eb0ba988f4cfca4399c92cd6bb7b4ae8665720c)
(cherry picked from commit 8aadd4ebdfea3f1b46b2e2e62b355e8b40b6261b)
(cherry picked from commit 3d3a263789c5cc49899d63d18f9233c981f5b894)

commit_message:
Fix pep8 errors found by hacking 2.0.0

Fix the following issues that are now exposed by hacking version 2.0.0

./networking_ovn/tests/unit/common/test_hash_ring_manager.py:92:38:
F602 dictionary key variable another_host_node repeated with different
values
 hash_dict_after_rebalance = {another_host_node: 'fake-uuid',

Also fixing

./networking_ovn/ovsdb/ovsdb_monitor.py:359:13: F841 local variable
'e' is assigned to but never used

But that is already fixed in the neutron repo, so this is only an
issue in networking-ovn repo.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/699083/
Change-Id: I9396d8af17d281eef15777e70a7d8fc0791f20b2
Signed-off-by: Flavio Fernandes <flaviof@redhat.com>
Co-authored-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Rodolfo Alonso Hernandez <ralonsoh@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit b869f30e0b082d789c6668ec1a3ee69f2142798e)

This change adds traps for the FileNotFound exception which is used instead
of OSError when a file is not found. This will ensure that that fall back
exception handeling works properly in py2 and py3.

The remote_src flag was not being respected with the new fallback options,
this change adds a check for remote_src so that works too.

commit_message:
Add traps for py3 and fix remote src

This change adds traps for the FileNotFound exception which is used instead
of OSError when a file is not found. This will ensure that that fall back
exception handeling works properly in py2 and py3.

The remote_src flag was not being respected with the new fallback options,
this change adds a check for remote_src so it works in normal and fallback
mode.

Change-Id: I136dd1f3220d3b004d5275a9fa15edea53d58f6b
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Properly set loopback_users via rabbitmq::loopback_users

Sorta resurrecting https://review.opendev.org/#/c/324016/ now that
https://github.com/voxpupuli/puppet-rabbitmq/pull/699 merged.

This commit prevents a duplicate entry for loopback_users in the
rabbitmq.config file:

{loopback_users, [<<"guest">>]},
{loopback_users, []},

keeping only the expected empty array.

Note: not a 100% clean cherry pick due to tht path changes.

(cherry picked from commit 04a5937e1f1482dd3115ddc809c555abea87e69d)

Change-Id: I0c291bf5611f02983c430179206556bae3b38736

commit_message:
Ignore devices with OSError

This bug handles OSError when trying to read from CDrom devices with no
disc in the is_pristine_disk function which makes the run-action
list-disks to fail.

Change-Id: I5e86895d1adff3f95c7feb5ed0f78b998c28ed1f
Depends-On: I951897a699305604821f2c910ee9ea91582c4e40
Closes-Bug: #1833857
Signed-off-by: Alexandros Soumplis <soumplis@admin.grnet.gr>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-09 14:12:58.000000000', 'message': 'Fix fluentd parsing of WSGI logs

WSGI log files use a different input configuration than OpenStack log
files. Currently this depends on log files matching either *-access.log
or *-error.log. Some services use *_access.log or *_error.log, so are
not parsed correctly.

This change modifies the fluentd configuration to accept an underscore
or hyphen for WSGI log file names.

Change-Id: I566d6cac0b6749054fd5422ec8f36f99dacb1db7
Closes-Bug: #1720371
'}]
commit_message:
Fix fluentd parsing of WSGI logs

WSGI log files use a different input configuration than OpenStack log
files. Currently this depends on log files matching either *-access.log
or *-error.log. Some services use *_access.log or *_error.log, so are
not parsed correctly.

This change modifies the fluentd configuration to accept an underscore
or hyphen for WSGI log file names.

Change-Id: I566d6cac0b6749054fd5422ec8f36f99dacb1db7
Closes-Bug: #1720371

Solve the problem when adding template

Fix the bug that when user adding a template in dashboard, it always toasts "Unable to validate the Vitrage Templates service.".

And CentOS had:

commit_message:
Fix monasca-grafana being unbuildable due to old npm

Affected builds on Ubuntu which had:
npm 3.5.2
while the latest was:
npm 6.13.4
And CentOS had:
npm 5.6.0

This patch runs npm update via npm.
Pinned to 6.x.

Additionally, this moves npm packages prefix (root) to
/usr/local to avoid conflicts with native packages.

Change-Id: Ibaacc1cc478b2b2f8196a5da4eea3570d7d310ff
Closes-bug: #1856699
(cherry picked from commit 308e85aa413da84ed107b27fa09a3f0e0a64392f)

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

specs repo either has py27 job or requirement or tox env.

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: I2e83ccb68edd2de7f6b14f9a55af6b1da895700d

- gate-pbr-installation-dsvm-upstream-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/44/470444/5/check/gate-pbr-installation-dsvm-upstream-ubuntu-xenial/e9dd1a4/ : SUCCESS in 21m 33s'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2017-06-03 18:49:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

It seems to me that if this is safe, it should be entirely reasonable to do the work in setuptools itself, rather than redundantly here. Given we talk about how open and collaborative we are, I'd like to suggest that we try getting a patch accepted there first :).

A simple import of pkg_resources shouldn't be a major perf issue - its 20ms on a hot disk cache, and no worse than 80ms on cold (with my testing on spinnning platters, n=~50).

Where the large anticipated cost is, is in the current algorithm in pkg_resources to retrieve versions: but thats fixable within setuptools, so we really should do that- unless there is some fundamental reason that setuptools can't be improved.

An alternate strategy would be to implement this in 'packaging' which is a package with the goal of encapsulating all the standards-agree-interop logic for Python, and where we probably want this glue to all live eventually anyway: but they won't accept a dep on setuptools I think, so we'd have a deeper stack to implement to make that patch be seriously considered."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2017-06-04 14:49:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I agree that we should fix the issue upstream. However, if we can show that this is a solid improvement, we can fix it here while we wait on fixing it in setuptools. This was spurred by people wanting to increase the job timeout value on devstack jobs because we've started spending so much time in 'openstack' invocations.

So yes, we should absolutely fix it properly, should we be able to characterize that it's a real problem and that there is a real solution. But there is no reason to not also backport a work around into our stack while we wait.

Re: perf - simply importing pkg_resources takes between 0.3 an 0.5 seconds for me. In the gate we have jobs running on VMs with very poor disk subsystems - and with many more python packages installed that have to be scanned. It's possible it could be even worse there. But we definitely need to gather more better data."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 03:19:20.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-18 11:57:20.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-06-02 21:38:09.000000000', 'message': "Write version info into and read from a file in the package

We currently load version information from python's pkg_resources
system. While that's wonderful and all, it's also rather expensive.

When we build the tarball or do an install, also write the version
information into {packagename}/__pbr_verison_info.py.

Then, put in logic in _get_version_from_pkg_resources to load from
the file in the package if it's there, avoiding the need to touch
pkg_resources and the load-time cost hit it incurs.

Change-Id: I46e65a1d4bd5cd8cd0b8efd118d13cab7c6e1925
"}, {'created': '2017-06-02 22:35:44.000000000', 'message': "Write version info into and read from a file in the package

We currently load version information from python's pkg_resources
system. While that's wonderful and all, it's also rather expensive.

When we build the tarball or do an install, also write the version
information into {packagename}/__pbr_verison_info.py.

Then, put in logic in _get_version_from_pkg_resources to load from
the file in the package if it's there, avoiding the need to touch
pkg_resources and the load-time cost hit it incurs.

Change-Id: I46e65a1d4bd5cd8cd0b8efd118d13cab7c6e1925
"}, {'created': '2017-06-02 23:47:35.000000000', 'message': "Write version info into and read from a file in the package

We currently load version information from python's pkg_resources
system. While that's wonderful and all, it's also rather expensive.

When we build the tarball or do an install, also write the version
information into {packagename}/__pbr_verison_info.py.

Then, put in logic in _get_version_from_pkg_resources to load from
the file in the package if it's there, avoiding the need to touch
pkg_resources and the load-time cost hit it incurs.

Change-Id: I46e65a1d4bd5cd8cd0b8efd118d13cab7c6e1925
"}, {'created': '2017-06-03 12:43:40.000000000', 'message': "Return version from egg-info and dist-info directly

Rather than using pkg-resources to read the version for a package, which
does a scan of all of the dirs on sys.path and then reading all of the
files in each of the egg-info and dist-info directories found, calculate
the directory from the module import and load the file.

This still will require a scan of the directory the module is in, which
is unavoidable because it's not possible to know the directory of the
metadata without knowing the version, but it should at least cut down
the number of directories scanned and the number of files read that
don't need to be read.

Change-Id: I46e65a1d4bd5cd8cd0b8efd118d13cab7c6e1925
"}, {'created': '2017-06-03 15:10:36.000000000', 'message': "Return version from egg-info and dist-info directly

Rather than using pkg-resources to read the version for a package, which
does a scan of all of the dirs on sys.path and then reading all of the
files in each of the egg-info and dist-info directories found, calculate
the directory from the module import and load the file.

This still will require a scan of the directory the module is in, which
is unavoidable because it's not possible to know the directory of the
metadata without knowing the version, but it should at least cut down
the number of directories scanned and the number of files read that
don't need to be read.

Change-Id: I46e65a1d4bd5cd8cd0b8efd118d13cab7c6e1925
"}]
commit_message:
Return version from egg-info and dist-info directly

Rather than using pkg-resources to read the version for a package, which
does a scan of all of the dirs on sys.path and then reading all of the
files in each of the egg-info and dist-info directories found, calculate
the directory from the module import and load the file.

This still will require a scan of the directory the module is in, which
is unavoidable because it's not possible to know the directory of the
metadata without knowing the version, but it should at least cut down
the number of directories scanned and the number of files read that
don't need to be read.

Change-Id: I46e65a1d4bd5cd8cd0b8efd118d13cab7c6e1925

[{'created': '2019-12-18 00:54:29.000000000', 'message': "Ensure option groups don't change during logging

oslo.config allows us to configure groups and options dynamically. This
can cause a race with our logging as we attempt to iterate through
option groups that are changing under our feet. This wouldn't be a huge
issue, since these are just logs are we can always log again, if needed,

the size of a dict it's iterating through:

commit_message:
Ensure option groups don't change during logging

oslo.config allows us to configure groups and options dynamically. This
can cause a race with our logging as we attempt to iterate through
option groups that are changing under our feet. This wouldn't be a huge
issue, since these are just logs are we can always log again, if needed,
but we store groups in a dictionary and Python doesn't like us changing
the size of a dict it's iterating through:

  RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during iteration

Given that we're only reading through this option group and don't need
to worry about a group _disappearing_, the solution is pretty simple:
create a copy of our option group names ahead of time so we don't need
to worry about new ones coming and messing things up.

No tests are included since this is a race and the only way I see to
reproduce this would involve lots of ugly threading.

Change-Id: Id3b28465d645a24f0fcebff2dd68a9bd30e21594
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1856312
(cherry picked from commit e3e2ba55eeeb86a9bc0624bb2592e46583e839e7)

oslo.config allows us to configure groups and options dynamically. This
can cause a race with our logging as we attempt to iterate through

commit_message:
Bump the openstackdocstheme extension to 1.20

Some options are now automatically configured by the version 1.20:
- project
- html_last_updated_fmt
- latex_engine
- latex_elements
- version
- release.

Change-Id: I394f36c791005e87f50f152cc723189dd40e9982

subject: Use topo ordering to correctly sort changelog entries
messages:
[{'account_id': 26923, 'date': '2017-09-19 18:56:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2017-09-19 18:56:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-09-19 23:01:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

commit_message:
Use topo ordering to correctly sort changelog entries

Call git log with --topo-order so that old changes merged in after a
tagged release do not appear in the changelog entries for that release.

Change-Id: I9ea5ef4d1d7c3ec4d57d17a40c67971c30ec6105

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-08-10 16:46:08.000000000', 'message': "Add support for a docs extra aligned with RTD locations

readthedocs.org looks for docs/requirements.txt and if found will
install those files before building docs. We currently lump all of our
doc requirements in with test requirements in OpenStack, which makes it
harder to keep clear why a particular requirement is desired.

Similar to parsing and adding test-requirements.txt to the test extra,
add an extra called 'docs' and put the contents of doc/requirements.txt
in it. This should allow us to have repos that are more generally
compatible with the wider ecosystem, and to stop installing
documentation generation packages for unittests if we don't otherwise
need to.

Change-Id: Ibc46e0132c233b6f7f2e9dfc6a6f8e2e2ed4643c
"}, {'created': '2017-11-09 06:27:34.000000000', 'message': "Add support for a docs extra aligned with RTD locations

readthedocs.org looks for docs/requirements.txt and if found will
install those files before building docs. We currently lump all of our
doc requirements in with test requirements in OpenStack, which makes it
harder to keep clear why a particular requirement is desired.

Similar to parsing and adding test-requirements.txt to the test extra,
add an extra called 'docs' and put the contents of doc/requirements.txt
in it. This should allow us to have repos that are more generally
compatible with the wider ecosystem, and to stop installing
documentation generation packages for unittests if we don't otherwise
need to.

Change-Id: Ibc46e0132c233b6f7f2e9dfc6a6f8e2e2ed4643c
"}]
commit_message:
Add support for a docs extra aligned with RTD locations

readthedocs.org looks for docs/requirements.txt and if found will
install those files before building docs. We currently lump all of our
doc requirements in with test requirements in OpenStack, which makes it
harder to keep clear why a particular requirement is desired.

Similar to parsing and adding test-requirements.txt to the test extra,
add an extra called 'docs' and put the contents of doc/requirements.txt
in it. This should allow us to have repos that are more generally
compatible with the wider ecosystem, and to stop installing
documentation generation packages for unittests if we don't otherwise
need to.

Change-Id: Ibc46e0132c233b6f7f2e9dfc6a6f8e2e2ed4643c

commit_message:
Fix failure of updating old version object

Update of old version object fails when
object doesn't have a attribute which
has been added newly in latest version.

We should consider this case by
accepting a NotImplementedError.

Closes-Bug: #1615922
Change-Id: I2c9773ba06aa5d7af0c4c74e3090e219843ed3e1

commit_message:
Change python3.5 job to python3.7 job on Stein+

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial, now that we have
Bionic Beaver nodes that support python3.7, lets switch to testing with
python3.7 in addition with python3.6 in Stein and beyond.
See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135632.html

Change-Id: If13bc1027ab9688815ed011380e61ef0f5c3c3a7
Signed-off-by: Charles Short <chucks@redhat.com>

This Timer object is a copy of the threading.Timer implementation,
except it uses the eventlet-aware Event implementation from

using the threading implementation with eventlet.

Change-Id: Ib727fb3fd67864a7334097e5bfeed694b39248ce
'}]
commit_message:
Add eventlet-aware Timer object to eventletutils

This Timer object is a copy of the threading.Timer implementation,
except it uses the eventlet-aware Event implementation from
eventletutils.  This avoids busy-waiting on Events that occurs when
using the threading implementation with eventlet.

Change-Id: Ib727fb3fd67864a7334097e5bfeed694b39248ce

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-08-29 12:25:50.000000000', 'message': 'Check for valid uuid length

A valid uuid consists of 32 characters and 4 -.
As per current behavior if user passes more -
in uuid (for example, aaaa---aaaa-aaaa----aaaa-aaaa---aaaa-aaaa-aaaa)
then is_uuit_like function treats it is valid uuid and returns True
because while checking it is replacing all - with empty string and
checking for 32 characters only. This is causing db error where in
database table uuid value is set to 36 but actual value of uuid is
greater than that.

To resolve this issue I have added a new method name as
"format_canonical_uuid" in the uuidutils module which will verify
the fixed number of hyphens in the uuid and convert it in a valid
format and returns otherwise treat it as invalid uuid and raise
ValueError with appropriate error message.

Related-Bug: #1680130
Change-Id: Ic2e9aabc644ef386813a03f1d7d570e86f8705af
'}, {'created': '2017-09-04 12:23:39.000000000', 'message': 'Check for valid uuid length

A valid uuid consists of 32 characters and 4 -(hyphens).
As per current behavior if user passes more -(hyphens)
in uuid (for example, aaaa---aaaa-aaaa----aaaa-aaaa---aaaa-aaaa-aaaa)
then is_uuit_like function treats it as valid uuid and returns True
because while checking it is replacing all - with empty string and
checking for 32 characters only. This is causing db error where in
database table uuid value is set to 36 but actual value of uuid is
greater than that.

To resolve this issue I have added a new method name as
"format_canonical_uuid" in the uuidutils module which will verify
the fixed number of hyphens in the uuid and convert it in a valid
format and returns otherwise treat it as invalid uuid and raise
ValueError with appropriate error message.

Related-Bug: #1680130
Change-Id: Ic2e9aabc644ef386813a03f1d7d570e86f8705af
'}]
commit_message:
Check for valid uuid length

A valid uuid consists of 32 characters and 4 -(hyphens).
As per current behavior if user passes more -(hyphens)
in uuid (for example, aaaa---aaaa-aaaa----aaaa-aaaa---aaaa-aaaa-aaaa)
then is_uuit_like function treats it as valid uuid and returns True
because while checking it is replacing all - with empty string and
checking for 32 characters only. This is causing db error where in
database table uuid value is set to 36 but actual value of uuid is
greater than that.

To resolve this issue I have added a new method name as
"format_canonical_uuid" in the uuidutils module which will verify
the fixed number of hyphens in the uuid and convert it in a valid
format and returns otherwise treat it as invalid uuid and raise
ValueError with appropriate error message.

Related-Bug: #1680130
Change-Id: Ic2e9aabc644ef386813a03f1d7d570e86f8705af

commit_message:
Allow 'forever_retry_uncaught_exceptions' to take a custom logger

Sometimes it is more appropriate to use a projects own logger
instead of the default root logger, so make such a thing possible
to do.

This also removes the usage of mox from the retry exception
testing and replaces it with mock instead (because the tests
were affected and just removing old & busted mox is easier at
this point).

Change-Id: Ia0f4adbc5f62be0a6a35a4c698b2779581171ca7

commit_message:
Add a safe_format to strutils

Formatting strings has the potential to be unsafe because it
allows access to builtins such as __class__, __init__, as indicated
in [1].

It's more dangerous when the format is used with a parameter that
is a Python object.

[1]: http://lucumr.pocoo.org/2016/12/29/careful-with-str-format/

Change-Id: I1300bac4276facf2fe16af1b7028f56bdc9b482f

- version
- release.

commit_message:
Run rootwrap with lower fd ulimit by default

On Python 2.x, a subprocess.Popen() with close_fds=True will
fork and then close filedescriptors range(3..os.sysconf("SC_OPEN_MAX")),
which thanks to Kernel PTI (Kaiser patches) is significantly slower
in 2018 when the range is very large. With a soft limit of 1048576,
benchmark.py reports an overhead of ~ 400ms without this patch and 2ms
with the patch applied. This patch adds a configuration option and
leaves it disabled for the stable/* backports to not change default
behavior.

Also includes Ben Nemec's release note entry, adjusted for the stable
backport. This is Ib29e96307caa39c21936f216d9aed7907e7a7331 for master.

Also includes I2391315f77718a3c9eb9fc8c03a6882237f33548 from master.

Also includes I3b481ddd14ae2b948270d715aad157cf3996def7 from master.

(cherry picked from commit c0a86998203315858721a7b2c8ab75fbf5cd51d9)
(cherry picked from commit 8f148f5e9e786d8a3922b0d5ae29bc54b8e8e1e9)
(cherry picked from commit 5259c08c09eb3aeab64af928cddf84bc213594d3)

Closes-Bug: 1796267
Closes-Bug: #1804639
Change-Id: Idd98c183eca3e2df8648fc0f37d27fe9cc6d0563
(cherry picked from commit c338f2c5c79abd44be5da495ae980fe7aefe194d)

commit_message:
Run rootwrap with lower fd ulimit by default

On Python 2.x, a subprocess.Popen() with close_fds=True will
fork and then close filedescriptors range(3..os.sysconf("SC_OPEN_MAX")),
which thanks to Kernel PTI (Kaiser patches) is significantly slower
in 2018 when the range is very large. With a soft limit of 1048576,
benchmark.py reports an overhead of ~ 400ms without this patch and 2ms
with the patch applied. This patch adds a configuration option and
leaves it disabled for the stable/* backports to not change default
behavior.

Also includes Ben Nemec's release note entry, adjusted for the stable
backport. This is Ib29e96307caa39c21936f216d9aed7907e7a7331 for master.

Also includes I2391315f77718a3c9eb9fc8c03a6882237f33548 from master.

Also includes I3b481ddd14ae2b948270d715aad157cf3996def7 from master.

[{'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-03-13 00:48:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-03-13 12:00:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Nice!  Wonder if we can get this merged and released if we can bump lower constraints, since we're past freeze, it was 2/25 http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/oslo-specs/specs/policy/feature-freeze.html"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-03-22 15:47:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Code looks good (minor comment in inline).

I'm just wondering how easy it is to fool this filter due to the regexp not being anchored at the start and end of string.

Have you considered using re.match() instead?"}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-03-22 16:55:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for the feedback. I'd definitely considered, that, but it's opposite the use case I'm aiming at, and ultimately not any better for lax patterns.  I.e.

re.seach('weak pattern' and re.match('.*weak pattern') become identical.

What we're trying to do is be able to match against specific python scripts. Right now, the packagers are adding /usr/bin/python as a kill filter, which is way too broad. Arguably, you can say, "use killfilter", but do "/usr/bin/python", "path/to/script", except that the path to both python and the script change based on the system, so most packagers end up with the general filter. We'd like to let the teams put in more specific filters that catch just the script they want.

Perhaps some more verbiage about the dangers of over-broad patterns?'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-03-25 11:15:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think you are right... It is easy for a local attacker to run something that would match the filter, but then the KillFilter could only be abused to send signals as root to that attacker-run process... which should not result in privilege escalation.

I guess I'm just worried about adding more functionality to oslo.rootwrap, rather than rely on oslo.privsep which is a much superior and secure implementation. Where do you plan to use that new filter ?"}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-03-25 14:50:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hmm, that's a good question. Neutron still uses rootwrap (and privsep), and this was to reduce the permission scope on its script management. Is the recommended way to do that to make a privsep function that does the same?"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-03-26 12:50:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yes, privsep is the future! We try to keep rootwrap in maintenance mode at this point, and generally encourage everyone to move to privsep which achieves better performance (no shell overhead) and security (reduced abuse potential).

That said, a new rootwrap filter is a sufficiently-contained change, so if doing the same in privsep is a hassle for any reason, I'm fine with the occasional rootwrap feature addition :) Your call."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-04-25 18:05:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Is this still needed? Worth noting that we now have some proper guidelines for implementing privsep'd methods thanks to Thierry: https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.privsep/latest/user/index.html"}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-06-10 15:21:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Marking WIP until we determine whether this is still needed. See previous comments for more discussion.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-18 11:47:05.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This has been marked WIP for some time with no follow-up. I'm going to abandon on the assumption it's not. Please reopen if this isn't the case"}]

subject: Avoid importing eventlet.patcher from cmd.py
messages:
[{'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-03-24 20:39:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-03-25 07:49:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-03-25 12:29:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-03-26 08:32:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-04-02 12:16:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Not convinced we need to use these changes.
I guess we risk to reintroduce an issue with the python 3 support by using these changes.

https://github.com/openstack/oslo.rootwrap/commit/31cfdbd4076bb6556cf9612171ba43fa44475d71'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-04-16 21:17:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I'm sorry, a -1 with something that I can't work on isn't helpful. The py3.x tests are passing. do you have any recommendation on what I should try to make this mergable?

The performance benefit here is non-neglectible and we certainly don't want 15MB of random python code to be imported in a security sensitive and timing sensitive application that runs under suid root, do we?"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-04-18 10:07:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

This patch is basically reverting 31cfdbd4, which was pushed by Victor Stinner to close hard-to-test issues around eventlet and Python3. So beyond passing py3 tests, we should definitely make sure that the issue Victor was fixing in that patch is no longer present, before approving this.

In particular:
"When eventlet is used (with monkey-patching or not), it's more
reliable to use eventlet.green.subprocess instead of using directly
subprocess from the Python standard library. On Python 2, it "works" to use directly subprocess: subprocess.Popen calls os.pipe() and os.fdopen(fd) which are both monkey-patched. On Python 3, it doesn't work because subprocess uses os.pipe() and io.open(fd), and the io module is *not* monkey-patched at all."

Were there some changes in recent eventlet/greenlet that would sidestep that old Python3/eventlet issue Victor was working around in his patch?'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-04-27 06:42:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I think I am not reverting his commit, the main thing I am doing is delaying the monkey patch import from __init__ into client.py so that the rootwrap cmd.py can be executed without importing eventlet. Cmd is standalone and as far as I can understand it is possible to write python 3 code using subprocess without having to use eventlet patching.

For the part that is imported by openstack services we continue to use the same patching logic than before, just a few instruction later.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-04-30 13:12:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(5 comments)

Sorry if comment first comment not brought enough informations. After more investigations I guess your changes can be accepted but before that we need to take care about some module imports like daemon, wrapper, etc...

Some refactors are needed to be sure to avoid to reintroduce the python3 issue.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-04-30 13:19:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Note that the wrapper module and the daemon module are also in use in the cmd module so I guess the more proper way to do that is to keep the original code of __init__.py and to move it to a dedicated module (you need to create it) and to design a kind of factory that will patch or not patch subprocess, or something like that to avoid to reintroduce the python3 issue and to avoid to monkey patch the stdlib if needed.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-05-03 16:51:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

We really need to becareful about this kind of changes.

Non patched subprocess at at the origin of the amqp uwsgi discussion on the ML [1] where the python interpreter become idle under uwsgi mode and also have impact on rabbitmq where connection heartbeat stop to work due to the same uwsgi problem where mistral call a ansible who use non patched subprocess to generate heartbeat.

To solve the previous issue we need to use oslo_rootwrap to use patched subprocess https://review.opendev.org/#/c/656901 

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005305.html
[2] https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1826281'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-05-03 16:54:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Workflow-1

Thanks for the detailed feedback, I will work on this. Is there any way we can pull up a unit test for the 'python3 issue'?"}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-05-09 12:57:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Thanks for the detailed feedback, I will work on this. Is there any
 > way we can pull up a unit test for the 'python3 issue'?

I agree the prior before that is to try to introduce test to avoid error with this kind of test.

I don't know how to test that for now... I can see that the Victor's original tests [1] are now in use [2] in oslo.rootwrap but I don't if it's enough and I guess no is not enough since your initial changes doesn't break the CI... 

I'll do some tests on my side to try to find a solution and I'll ping you when I'd find something interesting.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.rootwrap/commit/6f424f73cd340d1d6edd018de373430ca03712a6#diff-b91f3d5bd63fcd17221b267e851608e8R23

[2] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.rootwrap/blob/master/tox.ini#L16"}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-18 11:46:27.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

If this is still going to be worked on, it needs to be fixed up. I'm going to abandon this until that can happen"}]

[{'created': '2019-03-24 20:39:28.000000000', 'message': "Avoid importing eventlet.patcher from cmd.py

By importing eventlet.patcher from the main module initialisation,
we're importing a large part of code unnecessarily for the short-lived
rootwrap client case. With the existing code this is:

  $ time sudo /usr/bin/cinder-rootwrap /etc/cinder/rootwrap.conf id
  uid=0(root) gid=0(root) groups=0(root)

  real    0m4,067s
  user    0m0,821s
  sys     0m0,185s

This is because it imports various DNS and crypto libraries (which
in return do setup a lot of things like gather entropy and the like).
With this patch this reduces to:

  $ time sudo /usr/bin/cinder-rootwrap /etc/cinder/rootwrap.conf id

  real    0m1,279s
  user    0m0,192s
  sys     0m0,060s

which is, depending on which metrics you're looking at, up to 4 times
faster.

commit_message:
Avoid importing eventlet.patcher from cmd.py

By importing eventlet.patcher from the main module initialisation,
we're importing a large part of code unnecessarily for the short-lived
rootwrap client case. With the existing code this is:

  $ time sudo /usr/bin/cinder-rootwrap /etc/cinder/rootwrap.conf id
  uid=0(root) gid=0(root) groups=0(root)

  real    0m4,067s
  user    0m0,821s
  sys     0m0,185s

This is because it imports various DNS and crypto libraries (which
in return do setup a lot of things like gather entropy and the like).
With this patch this reduces to:

  $ time sudo /usr/bin/cinder-rootwrap /etc/cinder/rootwrap.conf id
  uid=0(root) gid=0(root) groups=0(root)

  real    0m1,279s
  user    0m0,192s
  sys     0m0,060s

which is, depending on which metrics you're looking at, up to 4 times
faster.

Change-Id: If098738924e78e76d1c19a329dd8db509022c922

(2 comments)

A debugging hint inline.'}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2017-03-14 07:00:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Is there any concrete issue you are trying to fix with this?

If we go this way, we loose some safety checks and useful logging. If following the tradition is the only reason to do this, I don't think we should. Besides, this daemon is not like usual Unix daemons - it's bound to the process that created it as it can only communicate with it. So there's no reason to not leave it as child (or grandchild) of parent process."}, {'account_id': 9200, 'date': '2017-03-14 08:00:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thanks for the review.

The reason is written in the commit message. With this patch, an idle sudo process can be eliminated per a rootwrap daemon.

As you pointed out, detaching is not strictly necessary as a rootwrap daemon should terminate anyway when its parent exits.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 03:56:44.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-18 11:45:53.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This has been open for a long time and in merge conflict for most of this. Time to let this go'}]

commit_message:
Detach from the parent using fork and exit

Today, every rootwrap daemon process is associated with its
parent sudo command, which serves no purpose.
In traditional unix programming, daemon processes call daemon(3)
to detach from their parents. Follow the tradition to kill those
useless sudo processes.

Change-Id: If824ccfa772404a40727b8dfd10c78da17730569

commit_message:
Expose caps values/names as int enum (WIP)

This avoids some of the lookup needed via globals()
and such to create a name and value mapping and makes
it a little easier to document the various caps.

Change-Id: I0325fc3229adfe851c4692e07d61433da3961c46

Keystone does not accept 'tag' attribute exposition within auth-token, so that I abandoned all commits at keystone side. However, new rule for tag is still valid to be reviewed.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-22 06:31:44.000000000', 'message': '[PoC] Add new kind of check called 'tags'

Add new check kind for matching tag. Auth token from Keystone now
exposes 'project_tags' and several sub components related to the
attribute now accept new attribute.

Admin can control this kind of check using tag based policy per
project. Possible use cases are look like

- "tags:production"
- "tags:develop"
- "tags:staging and tags:test"
- "tags:%(tags)"

Tag is orginally list attribute so that this kind of check match
two specified lists are overlapped. If there were any matched tagging
from two lists, check returns True.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/654301
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/654309
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/654307

commit_message:
[PoC] Add new kind of check called 'tags'

Add new check kind for matching tag. Auth token from Keystone now
exposes 'project_tags' and several sub components related to the
attribute now accept new attribute.

Admin can control this kind of check using tag based policy per
project. Possible use cases are look like

- "tags:production"
- "tags:develop"
- "tags:staging and tags:test"
- "tags:%(tags)s"

Tag is orginally list attribute so that this kind of check match
two specified lists are overlapped. If there were any matched tagging
from two lists, check returns True.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/654301
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/654309
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/654307
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/654305

Change-Id: I7f450344d93424dc6c9379ae905e87f8f0dac09b
Closes-bug: #1807697
Closes-bug: #1825336

commit_message:
Create OPA check

This creates a simple check that uses Open Policy Agent to evaluate
policy.

The recommended deployment is to use a system daemon or a sidecar
container, so the code is pretty simple to address that. However, it is
possible to use TLS for authentication/authorization, thus the option to
use TLS is available here.

Change-Id: Idd909c515a327bf20bb098b7ea708d7a2b549f16

commit_message:
Do not bind python2 specific directory into container

Use more generic path to place storlets python codes, so that
we can use the same path for python2 and python3.

Change-Id: Ia4ee0790ea58a42173f58bed2f59249c0b7edfd9

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-04 12:11:11.000000000', 'message': "Software RAID: Identify the root fs via its UUID from image metadata

In order to install the bootloader on instances with software RAID,
the IPA needs to chroot into the deployed image's root fs. Currently,
the IPA assumes the first partition to contain the root fs, so this
breaks with images where this is not the case. The proposed change
extracts the root fs UUID from the image's metadata instead and
passes it to the IPA (in the same way this is done for partition
images). It keeps the current behaviour to send the UUID extracted
from the driver internal info in case the metadata is not set on
the image. For the time being, the IPA completely ignores the UUID
passed anyway, so to make this fully work the IPA will also need
to be patched.

Change-Id: I69bd53aa24b7b10384dc1399a0acaa21d38d6bd9
Story: #2006649

commit_message:
Software RAID: Identify the root fs via its UUID from image metadata

In order to install the bootloader on instances with software RAID,
the IPA needs to chroot into the deployed image's root fs. Currently,
the IPA assumes the first partition to contain the root fs, so this
breaks with images where this is not the case. The proposed change
extracts the root fs UUID from the image's metadata instead and
passes it to the IPA (in the same way this is done for partition
images). It keeps the current behaviour to send the UUID extracted
from the driver internal info in case the metadata is not set on
the image. For the time being, the IPA completely ignores the UUID
passed anyway, so to make this fully work the IPA will also need
to be patched.

Change-Id: I69bd53aa24b7b10384dc1399a0acaa21d38d6bd9
Story: #2006649
Task: #37081

commit_message:
[WIP] Add OpenTracing instrumentation

This patch switches instrumentation from osprofiler to
opentracing to allow all consumers of keystoneauth library
to become compatible with OpenTracing (ex. CNCF Jaeger).

Refs:
 [1] Mail thread:
     http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005006.html
 [2] All patches in series:
     https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:open+topic:opentracing

Change-Id: I5c36efa74a92cf38731d21abfecd1b0a19974cce

commit_message:
[WIP] Make osprofiler OpenTracing-compatible

Changes:
 * Switch to OpenTracing instrumentation in web middleware, sqlalchemy
   handlers and trace decorator
 * Add OpenTracing-compatible tracer that reports spans in existing \
   osprofiler format

Refs:
 [1] Mail thread:
     http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005006.html
 [2] All patches in series:
     https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:open+topic:opentracing

// osc_lib
Depends-On: Ia26f85227ef1c188217355d57546cb54ee8c97c4

// keystoneauth
Depends-On: I5c36efa74a92cf38731d21abfecd1b0a19974cce

Change-Id: I5381622d0b9256d82b39c9d27069c2a0848ec1c5

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-26 10:50:40.000000000', 'message': 'Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for feature/nats-driver

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as feature/nats-driver branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I7bef96165091b2b1af1dd0735e70737d31144500
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for feature/nats-driver

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as feature/nats-driver branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I7bef96165091b2b1af1dd0735e70737d31144500

commit_message:
Remove some description from oslo policy

A lot of the content about how rules work and the rule syntax from
https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.policy/latest/reference/api/oslo_policy.policy.html
should move somewhere into the user section of that guide. That
probably means moving it out of the source code and into the doc tree.

bug-list https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.policy/+bug/1713055

Change-Id: I3e8a3f7cf3b1f5aca130b2e7866c47731061eb2c

commit_message:
Remove oslo_middleware.http_proxy_to_wsgi marked in ssl

HTTP proxy to WSGI termination middleware was no longer needed in
SSLMiddleware in new release, and it was deprecated for removal.

Change-Id: If888487d184ddc3eedb8612829f0fc6a71ccbcd4
Closes-Bug: #1715096

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-12 17:11:10.000000000', 'message': 'Change python3.5 job to python3.7 job on Stein+

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial, now that we have
Bionic Beaver nodes that support python3.7, lets switch to testing with
python3.7 in addition with python3.6 in Stein and beyond.
See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135632.html

Change-Id: Idcd8fd73efddf9ef82dcb55ebbc20c8f08bcfb6d
Signed-off-by: Charles Short <chucks@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Change python3.5 job to python3.7 job on Stein+

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial, now that we have
Bionic Beaver nodes that support python3.7, lets switch to testing with
python3.7 in addition with python3.6 in Stein and beyond.
See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135632.html

Change-Id: Idcd8fd73efddf9ef82dcb55ebbc20c8f08bcfb6d
Signed-off-by: Charles Short <chucks@redhat.com>

With this, I'm sure we will missed to configure the logger correctly next times a file is added.

The backwards compatibility is broken since a while, I'm not convinced we should add such technical debt to restore it.

I will raise that on next meeting.

Anyways, if we really go that way, please at least make a helper method like utils.getLogger instead of doing the same thing again and again."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2016-05-03 15:02:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Mehdi, we did make the decision to use oslo.* for logger names when we broke out the libraries, and to retain those names after we removed the namespace package. I think the implementation of the shift from the namespace packages failed to keep the names, though. I agree we should discuss this and decide on a path, document it, then be consistent. If that means we need to update oslo.log to treat some logger names in a special way (for backwards compatibility), that's OK as long as we all agree it's the right thing."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-05-18 16:56:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

This change or one of its cross-repo dependencies was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of its repository. Please rebase the change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 05:16:46.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-18 11:08:46.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

While I like the idea, I agree that this is something we should have a helper for. We probably want a bug report too. I'm going to abandon this for now since it's in merge conflict for some time, but if you want to repropose it then just ping me and I'll review."}]

commit_message:
Move all loggers under 'oslo.' package namespace

Replace all the non-namespaced prefixs 'oslo_' of loggers names with 'oslo.'
to maintain backward compatibility with log level configurations in production
For example: oslo=WARN or oslo.messaging=INFO

You can find the discussion about it here:
(see Doug Hellmann comments)
  - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/303581/

Change-Id: I15d1216a2554da950d09624dc98bcc4dd0be294f

commit_message:
Retry to declare a queue after internal error

Without this commit, the client can lose the messages, because the
client does not handler the 'AMQP internal error 541',
read here [2] for details.
The fix retries to create the queue after a delay.
When the virtual-host is ready the declare does not fail.
This is a rare condiction, please read the bug [1] for details.

Closes-Bug: #1822778

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+bug/1822778
[2] https://www.rabbitmq.com/amqp-0-9-1-reference.html

Change-Id: I7ab1f9d21ebb807285bf1422bc14cc6e07dcd32a
(cherry picked from commit 4d2787227b00b973973554f7387e621d2664c0d8)
