messages:
[{'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2018-12-06 16:40:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2018-12-06 16:41:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 23630, 'date': '2018-12-06 17:03:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thank Ken.

I will test this patch.

Also, I add some other people in Performance Team here. Hope this patch will move forward.'}, {'account_id': 21470, 'date': '2018-12-06 18:34:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hey ! 
Two quicks questions:
1) Do we want to differentiate between call and cast ?
2) Do we want to add traces on the client side or server side or both ?'}, {'account_id': 5950, 'date': '2018-12-07 16:13:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2018-12-07 18:42:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Hey there Matthieu!  Missed you in Berlin (I had to drink alone)

This patch doesn't add a trace point, it merely transports the trace context across the RPC call so the handling of the call can be included in the current trace.

IOW this doesn't trace oslo.messaging specifically but allows tracing the application's RPC calls.  We leave the job of adding tracepoints to the application. 

With this patch folks can add trace points around the RPC handlers on the server so they can trace the flow on the server.

You make a good point regarding cast (and fanout) - these operations are asynchronous so the trace point on the client will probably end before the server starts it's tracepoint.  So tracing casts and fanounts will not be linear like call/response.

Should we prevent tracing in the case of cast and fanout?"}, {'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2018-12-07 19:21:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2018-12-07 20:02:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 21470, 'date': '2018-12-17 10:07:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Ken,

Sorry, I've been too quick at reading the patch -- but I got your point now !
Regarding cast/fanout, ideally the user should be able to rebuild the flow. That's why I was thinking that the user should be able to differentiate cast/call/fanout when reading the traces. But that's maybe part of another patch."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-18 11:03:12.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This is in merge conflict and needs some work to move things along. I'm going to abandon for now to keep our review queue clear. Please reopen if we're still doing this."}]

commit_message:
RFC: Add osprofiler tracing for RPC calls

This proposed patch will integrate osprofiling into the RPC library to
allow projects to trace flows across RPC calls.

Projects like Nova and Neutron have taken steps to instrument their
code to support tracing across RPC calls.  This patch is based on
their work (IIUC this patch will not conflict with their
implementation - TBD if true)

Projects that want to trace across RPC calls will need to add
tracepoints as necessary to client code making RPC calls and wrap the
endpoint classes on the server properly - see the additional unit test
as an example.

Change-Id: I0bcf7ec932d0d9282b3063dccb7107e69e62eb21

commit_message:
Tell the multinode subnode and grenade to use /opt

It was changed on the primary node, but not the subnode
of the standard mutlinode job, and not updated on our
grenade job.

Changes subnode and grenade configuration to use it.

Change-Id: I8f67e3e3423e72944d22d65b788af5792ee900f9

[{'created': '2016-03-17 19:04:44.000000000', 'message': "WIP Queue messages on consumer rather than an external queue

This is a rough PoC on how this might be achieved. This is motivated by
a few goals:

1. It would be nice to have RPC dispatch prioritize different methods.

2. It would be nice to queue messages in a place that a service can
introspect easily. RabbitMQ appears to be the commonly used queue at the
moment but it's not easy to query it in order to determine if some RPC
call is in the queue vs it was consumed and dropped.

Change-Id: If669f7c5578bbc4e55379af4c3b901ee98eb0bec
"}]
commit_message:
WIP Queue messages on consumer rather than an external queue

This is a rough PoC on how this might be achieved. This is motivated by
a few goals:

1. It would be nice to have RPC dispatch prioritize different methods.

2. It would be nice to queue messages in a place that a service can
introspect easily. RabbitMQ appears to be the commonly used queue at the
moment but it's not easy to query it in order to determine if some RPC
call is in the queue vs it was consumed and dropped.

Change-Id: If669f7c5578bbc4e55379af4c3b901ee98eb0bec

(2 comments)

-1 for the python3 failure.'}, {'account_id': 741, 'date': '2016-05-11 09:06:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

(Still untested, so not going to +1 - but would otherwise)'}, {'account_id': 13290, 'date': '2016-05-11 14:47:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

OK, I'm not putting the -1/-2 here, just trying to make my point that we open the Dispatcher class to a public and it feels not clear enough for me.

About StatsD as far as I understand a better way to count any RPC stats (my opinion) in endpoints and probably to provide some decorators or some polymorphism to existing endpoints. Why the dispatcher should be the place to do so?

Supporting acks for Mistral is definitely a vote for new dispatcher here.

Expected exceptions probably also extension for existing dispatcher and more clear way is to provide some means to pass a list of expected exceptions to the dispatcher rather than implement a new one for that reason?"}, {'account_id': 741, 'date': '2016-05-11 22:15:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> About StatsD as far as I understand a better way to count any RPC stats (my opinion) in endpoints and probably to provide some decorators or some polymorphism to existing endpoints. Why the dispatcher should be the place to do so?

So - That was a made up example of something I've considered, but not done... Anyway! It's often useful to have 1 place you say "Record all RPC method calls to all endpoints, their timings, their success rates" etc, vs decorating each method (duplication, methods will be missed) - or decorating the class (But - What about private methods? Or public methods not expected to be called over RPC?).

Allowing for this kind of thing seems reasonable, and I believe the dispatcher is the place that has all the appropriate information, as is it "closest" to the actual application itself.

Again - StatsD was a made up example, but one I've thought about doing more than once :)

> Supporting acks for Mistral is definitely a vote for new dispatcher here.

Yea, Pre vs Post ask feels like something o.m should provide out of the box, no argument there, even if making that work cross all of the available drivers is hard to impossible!

> Expected exceptions probably also extension for existing dispatcher and more clear way is to provide some means to pass a list of expected exceptions to the dispatcher rather than implement a new one for that reason?

This is by far the worst reason to allow it, but the one Designate (ab)uses. I believe we "miss" valuable errors in areas where something marked expected is actually unexpected, so I'd argue against oslo.messaging including this. Regardless, it's something we've had for 3+ releases so even if we rework it today, we have to support for a good while to come.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-05-12 23:28:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Soooo where do we want to take this :-P'}, {'account_id': 13290, 'date': '2016-05-12 23:53:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

As I can see from here https://github.com/openstack/designate/blob/master/designate/rpc.py
people will hack RPC layer anyway :), so lets allow them to do that legally, so they wouldn't manually create the server object at least :) Need the final word from Mehdi."}, {'account_id': 13290, 'date': '2016-05-13 00:06:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

And this one https://github.com/openstack/mistral/blob/master/mistral/engine/rpc.py#L49 I'd move to oslo.messaging and turn dispatcher into a stevedore driver. What do you think?"}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2016-05-13 13:11:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I think we already do a big mistake by making the dispatcher available publicly...

I don't see what this patch add to oslo.messaging, this is already possible to 'hack' the dispatcher because we infortunately make it public.

About the oslo.msg 5.0 API breakage, this is because some people thinks RPCDispatcher/MessagingServer are public, some other private. I warn about the breakable in previous reviews. But we finally lands the patch.

The only good fix for a lib when API breakage occurs is to restore the backward compatibility, but nobody take the time to do it. People prefer to fix their application instead of blacklisting this broken version from requirements and participate to the lib to fix it..."}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2016-05-13 13:13:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Also dispatcher implementation is linked to the driver implementation. This is why I think that should be private.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-05-13 22:07:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

So I wonder what the best approach is to reach consensus here.

Some people are hacking up this dispatcher in unwanted ways, and it seems like we want to make it private (when it was sort of semi-public before) to stop these types of bad behaviors.

But if we do that then these other projects will likely resort to more hacking apart things (sadly).

Probably should move this to the mailing list to see if we can reach a broader audience since I'm not sure what's the best path here myself..."}, {'account_id': 9796, 'date': '2016-05-16 03:13:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

+1 for mailing list. The ideal target is that oslo.messaging holds common dispatchers, customers implements dispatcher as stevedore driver if it is not suitable for others.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-05-20 05:33:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Parts of mailing list @ http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-May/095302.html'}, {'account_id': 13290, 'date': '2016-06-12 22:16:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 05:13:48.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-18 11:01:55.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This has been open for a long time with open comments. I think it's time to abandon things until when/if someone wants to pick it up again"}]

[{'created': '2016-08-18 13:00:55.000000000', 'message': "Fix socket getting in the set_transport_socket_timeout()

The set_transport_socket_timeout() use self.channel to obtain the socket,
but if during reconnection the set_transport_socket_timeout was called
before _set_current_channel(new_channel) it leads to the:

[-] Failed to get socket attribute: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'sock' set_transport_socket_timeout

because self.channel was closed at this moment.

So, to fix it just use self.connection.connection.sock instead of
self.channel.*

Change-Id: I0dae7ee96ce052dec4c71c06b975966596cae011

commit_message:
Fix socket getting in the set_transport_socket_timeout()

The set_transport_socket_timeout() use self.channel to obtain the socket,
but if during reconnection the set_transport_socket_timeout was called
before _set_current_channel(new_channel) it leads to the:

[-] Failed to get socket attribute: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'sock' set_transport_socket_timeout

because self.channel was closed at this moment.

So, to fix it just use self.connection.connection.sock instead of
self.channel.*

Change-Id: I0dae7ee96ce052dec4c71c06b975966596cae011

commit_message:
Fix tox environments

Work items:

* Removed the globale-requirements constraint. Since python-cloudkittyclient
  is now part of the global requirements, the upstream requirements
  file can't be used anymore.

* Add cliff to docs requirements.

* Change cloudkittyclient namespace names: Having a dot in a namespace
  name causes the "autoprogram-cliff" to use the "application mode".

Change-Id: I8020d816b3397550fbcbd42cc14a9861bca7ae80

commit_message:
Stop configuring install_command in tox.

Currently, we are overriding 'install_command' to use 'pip'. This is
considered poor behavior and 'python -m pip' should be used instead:

https://snarky.ca/why-you-should-use-python-m-pip/

It turns out that this is the the default value provided by tox:

https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-install_command

So we can remove the line and simply use the default value.

Change-Id: I5b32b7558525065847550f422b86e12281f71a8a

subject: force log_opt_values looping through a list copy
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-13 12:45:17.000000000', 'message': 'force log_opt_values looping through a list copy

Under rare cases, during running log_opt_values method, a different thread may try to
register new groups which will eventually raise an runtime error. So I think it is safer
to first make a copy of keys and going through them.

bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1856312
Change-Id: I17492a216579bed85e935e72506e491f22fee84f
'}]
commit_message:
force log_opt_values looping through a list copy

Under rare cases, during running log_opt_values method, a different thread may try to
register new groups which will eventually raise an runtime error. So I think it is safer
to first make a copy of keys and going through them.

bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1856312
Change-Id: I17492a216579bed85e935e72506e491f22fee84f

switch ports solely based on whether the port security was enabled or
disabled. That's not how it's intended to work.

With this patch the "unknown" address is only set to the normal logical

commit_message:
Only set "unknown" in LSP that makes sense

Prior to this patch, the "unknown" address was being set the logical
switch ports solely based on whether the port security was enabled or
disabled. That's not how it's intended to work.

With this patch the "unknown" address is only set to the normal logical
switch ports, those which types are "router", "localnet" or "localport"
won't be affected.

The maintenance task was updated to correct this behavior for existing
ports (the maintenance was suppose to be removed in the T cycle, this
patch bumps it to U cycle instead due to this change).

Closes-Bug: #1838535
Related-Bug: #1815270
Change-Id: I3c01bd7d1685c8a7e13a55e545e98baf19e9a0f9
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Create Validations logging directory

The Validation framework is logging every execution in the
/var/log/validations directory and this one should be created first.

This patch also get rid of the validations user creation because we
don't need anymore since Mistral is out for the validator CLI.

Change-Id: I502c38d3f27db3c6f62a47190136dd03627956bc
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Cache security group driver

Change I0932c652fb455fe10239215a93e183ea947234e3 from Mitaka
was a performance improvement to cache the loaded security
group driver since the API calls get_openstack_security_group_driver
a lot. That performance fix was regressed with change
Ia4a8d9954bf456253101b936f8b4ff513aaa73b2 in Newton.

This caches the loaded security group driver once again. This
is pretty similar to the original change except simpler since
we don't have to account for the skip_policy_check flag.

Change-Id: Icacc763f19db6dc90e72af32e17d480775ad5edf
Closes-Bug: #1825018
(cherry picked from commit 0461921d9e5313c3e92b039b90f713ed961e20c8)

commit_message:
Use "via" in gateway dictionary in Linux Bridge agent

The gateway IP address in the gateway dictionary returned by
"ip_lib.list_ip_routes" is stored in "via".

"priority" parameter is changed to "metric", to match input and
output parameters.

Change-Id: I67ae473dca8d706f963c3b55b9410f9a79d7f32b
Closes-Bug: #1855759

commit_message:
Add netcontrold service for DPDK roles

netcontrold rebalances the overloaded queues within
available PMD threads to avoid packet loss. Add
support to enable this service in the DPDK deployments.

Change-Id: Ia0ec2a3db0626e9a93ef591d0bc4f3a53d98820f
(cherry picked from commit 4d3b5be7e6fc40aa9491f33562456de0688aa0d5)

Sorta resurrecting https://review.opendev.org/#/c/324016/ now that
https://github.com/voxpupuli/puppet-rabbitmq/pull/699 merged.

This commit prevents a duplicate entry for loopback_users in the
rabbitmq.config file:

keeping only the expected empty array.

commit_message:
Properly set loopback_users via rabbitmq::loopback_users

Sorta resurrecting https://review.opendev.org/#/c/324016/ now that
https://github.com/voxpupuli/puppet-rabbitmq/pull/699 merged.

This commit prevents a duplicate entry for loopback_users in the
rabbitmq.config file:

{loopback_users, [<<"guest">>]},
{loopback_users, []},

keeping only the expected empty array.

Change-Id: I0c291bf5611f02983c430179206556bae3b38736
(cherry picked from commit 04a5937e1f1482dd3115ddc809c555abea87e69d)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-13 22:17:42.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Add ntpdate to ensure hwclock sync"

This reverts commit 0a6199bded71ee5b478e6a5982f5958bdcb6484b.

This doesn't actually work because if ntpd is started, 
ntpdate cannot run. We would need another solution to
ensure the system clock is synced under ntp.  The ntpdate
service is a oneshot service so it just runs a single
ntpdate (and hwclock) on boot.

Change-Id: Iaed98cbc3a15defbd07f54d7e3f49676011038d5
Related-Bug: #1856259
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Add ntpdate to ensure hwclock sync"

This reverts commit 0a6199bded71ee5b478e6a5982f5958bdcb6484b.

This doesn't actually work because if ntpd is started, 
ntpdate cannot run. We would need another solution to
ensure the system clock is synced under ntp.  The ntpdate
service is a oneshot service so it just runs a single
ntpdate (and hwclock) on boot.

Change-Id: Iaed98cbc3a15defbd07f54d7e3f49676011038d5
Related-Bug: #1856259

subject: Add load_balancer_id earlier to amphora info
messages: [{'account_id': 7249, 'date': '2019-12-02 18:56:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7249, 'date': '2019-12-02 19:52:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 7249, 'date': '2019-12-18 05:33:06.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nIn favor of https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698082'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-02 18:56:19.000000000', 'message': "Add load_balancer_id earlier to amphora info

When we create amphora for specific loadbalancer it would be
good to get info about mapping pair loadbalancer-amphora as
soon as possible.

For example, if admin need to debug some issues with amphora VMs
- loadbalancer_id won't be set until AmphoraComputeConnectivityWait
task succeded, so he has to go to worker logs to understand
which amphora is related to currently creating loadbalancer.

To simplify that - if amphora is creating for loadbalancer
add setting loadbalancer_id in UpdateAmphoraInfo task (pass as
an optional argument).

Change-Id: Ibf30f6368cb811043962844ae5f89e9dfcae2361
"}, {'created': '2019-12-02 19:52:48.000000000', 'message': "Add load_balancer_id earlier to amphora info

When we create amphora for specific loadbalancer it would be
good to get info about mapping pair loadbalancer-amphora as
soon as possible.

For example, if admin needs to debug connectivity issues with amphora 
VMs - loadbalancer_id won't be set until AmphoraComputeConnectivityWait
task succeded,( which is never for such case) so he has to go to worker 
logs to understand which amphora is related to currently creating 
loadbalancer.

To simplify that - if amphora is creating for loadbalancer
add setting loadbalancer_id in UpdateAmphoraInfo task (pass as
an optional argument).

Change-Id: Ibf30f6368cb811043962844ae5f89e9dfcae2361
"}]
commit_message:
Add load_balancer_id earlier to amphora info

When we create amphora for specific loadbalancer it would be
good to get info about mapping pair loadbalancer-amphora as
soon as possible.

For example, if admin needs to debug connectivity issues with amphora 
VMs - loadbalancer_id won't be set until AmphoraComputeConnectivityWait
task succeded,( which is never for such case) so he has to go to worker 
logs to understand which amphora is related to currently creating 
loadbalancer.

To simplify that - if amphora is creating for loadbalancer
add setting loadbalancer_id in UpdateAmphoraInfo task (pass as
an optional argument).

Change-Id: Ibf30f6368cb811043962844ae5f89e9dfcae2361

commit_message:
OvS DPDK parameters failing in NIC Partitioning

This change is to fix the finding DPDK device name issue in
OvS DPDK derive parameters logic. Currently mistral fails to
derive OvS DPDK parameters in NIC Partitioning and getting
error 'Unable to determine NUMA node for DPDK NIC:'

Change-Id: I8dfc2494d35d5fce52d573f9edcafbe11ab7faac
Closes-Bug: #1855159
(cherry picked from commit 9641cc2ccb9d6bc5757f2bb888b374dedc2d2733)
(cherry picked from commit dd354ee4d6eb05c003de40006cbdb0895099f2c8)

commit_message:
Remove unused arguments in test methods

"testtool" library do not pass arguments to the test methods when
executing the tests, except for those ones decorated with mock
patches.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I623f9a80541b7fd06edce05722577f7cb4d7a653

commit_message:
CiscoNexus: Update and Remove deprecated vars

Backward compatible backport (modified by hand).

Update and Remove deprecated variables from Cisco Nexus Config.
* Deprecated variables include vlan_name_prefix, svi_round_robin,
  provider_vlan_name_prefix, persistent_switch_config,
  never_cache_ssh_connection, ssh_port, switch_replay_count,
  nexus_driver, and host_key_checks.
* Change config replay to on by defaulting switch_heartbeat_time=30.
* Replaced method of configurating host_ports_mapping config.

Change-Id: Iee2f869c4054f1120d224994aba8c827f981e6c0
Closes-bug:  #1793379
(cherry picked from commit f45169f38db4333d60841136fe3fab951221eeb6)

'}, {'created': '2018-10-17 22:57:50.000000000', 'message': 'Fix IPv6 and add initial boot-from-url

Adds logic to handle the appropriate replies for DHCPv6
responses in order to lay the groundwork for HTTPClient
Boot From URL support.

The IPv6 nature was discovered while researching differences
and finding that the field ID value changes between IPv4 and
IPv6 DHCP clients, as DHCPv6 is purely booting from a URL.

Task: 9788
Story: 1744620
Story: 2003934
Task: 26844
Change-Id: I4035f850e309d35c58395e388e8a2ac68617092c
'}, {'created': '2018-10-18 13:57:14.000000000', 'message': 'wip: Add boot from http url

In order to support the appropriate reply to the requests
a HTTPClient may be looking for, we need to reply with a
HTTP(s) URL.

Story: 2003934
Task: 26844
Change-Id: I4035f850e309d35c58395e388e8a2ac68617092c
'}, {'created': '2019-12-18 00:21:58.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Add boot from http url

In order to support the appropriate reply to the requests
a HTTPClient may be looking for, we need to reply with a
HTTP(s) URL.

Story: 2003934
Task: 26844
Change-Id: I4035f850e309d35c58395e388e8a2ac68617092c
'}]
commit_message:
WIP: Add boot from http url

In order to support the appropriate reply to the requests
a HTTPClient may be looking for, we need to reply with a
HTTP(s) URL.

Story: 2003934
Task: 26844
Change-Id: I4035f850e309d35c58395e388e8a2ac68617092c

Avoid referenced before assignment in retry_on_conflict

Raising pure exception to avoid referenced before assignment
error and actually see the exception.

Change-Id: I86424d989a6ec343134f6fac3e777a9e3e59eef0

commit_message:
Fix type on py3

This shouldn't have any practical effect, since *any* False-y value for
chunk will give us the correct behavior, but let's be consistent in the
type used with that name.

Change-Id: I1928883792e7a9945f3731ddeea992d14882d679

subject: Get Trove running at Home in a Nutshell
messages:
[{'account_id': 29159, 'date': '2019-01-29 16:04:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-01-29 16:04:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-01-30 05:21:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hello Cezary Żukowski,

I noticed you had submitted your first patch to OpenStack! Congratulations! I just wanted to reach out and follow up with you on the comments on your patch to see if you need any help. We want to help you get your patch merged and help you be successful in our community! 

Please let us know if you have any questions about your patch, the review process, or the community itself. 

I have added a trove dev, Zhao Chao, to your patch who can help you along your OpenStack journey!

Hope to hear from you soon, 

Matthew Oliver (mattoliverau) and the rest of the First Contact SIG'}, {'account_id': 22694, 'date': '2019-01-31 07:39:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For a long time, the installation of Trove has always been a headache (especially in China or other areas with poor network). This document looks very detailed.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-12-18 00:59:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

adding Kong to notice this.'}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2019-12-18 01:58:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Hi Cezary, thanks for submitting this patch, here are my suggestions:

1. This doc is especially for the contributor, I'd suggest creating a new section under `Contributor Resources` in Trove official doc https://docs.openstack.org/trove/latest/ to cover the steps of virtualbox VM preparation.
2. For devstack installation, we already have the doc here https://docs.openstack.org/trove/latest/install/install-devstack.html
3. For image build, see here https://docs.openstack.org/trove/latest/admin/building_guest_images.html#building-guest-images. However, the devstack will by default build and register the mysql image actually.
4. Please use 'openstack' command instead of 'trove'.
5. For Trove installation verification(creating the first trove instance), see here https://docs.openstack.org/trove/latest/contributor/how_to_create_a_trove_instance.html"}]

commit_message:
Get Trove running at Home in a Nutshell

The guide comprises:

1) installing Trove in VirtualBox on your laptop
2) building a working MySQL image for MySQL datastore
3) verifying Trove installation - creating a database and
   writing/reading some data around

Change-Id: Iadaab9336fc9466bd1486479ff51a5ae82603b15
Signed-off-by: Cezary Zukowski <c.zukowski@partner.samsung.com>

commit_message:
[ceph-client] update pool validation logic

Starting in Nautilus, setting pgp_num step is no longer necessary
as long as pgp_num and pg_num currently match, pgp_num will automatically
track any pg_num changes.
More importantly, the adjustment of pgp_num to migrate data and (eventually)
converge to pg_num is done gradually to limit the data migration load on the system.

Change-Id: I491b6eac35b486698c0eef256ca91dac217f8929

for a revertResize server action.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

commit_message:
Add revert_snapshot_based_resize conductor RPC method

This adds the conductor ComputeTaskManager method
revert_snapshot_based_resize along with the related conductor
RPC API client method which will be an RPC cast from the API
for a revertResize server action.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: Ia6b6b25238963a5f60349267da6d07cb740982f4

messages:
[{'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-13 16:24:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-13 17:29:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Yup looks good and it aligns where the traceback in the bug:

2019-12-13 06:53:22.911 29036 ERROR nova self.conf.log_opt_values(LOG, logging.DEBUG)
2019-12-13 06:53:22.911 29036 ERROR nova File "/var/lib/openstack/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/oslo_config/cfg.py", line 2579, in log_opt_values'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-13 17:30:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29071, 'date': '2019-12-13 23:52:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi, why you submit another identical ps, what is the prolem with this one https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698892/?'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-16 09:26:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Hi, why you submit another identical ps, what is the prolem with
 > this one https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698892/?

Ah, sorry, I simply didn't see it. If you want patches to be linked against their launchpad bug, you need to include the 'Closes-Bug: #NNNNNNN' footer in the commit message. Without this, they don't bubble up and it's just chance whether someone will find it.

I'm tempted to keep this one because they were submitted quite close to each other and this commit message is more detailed, but I will let someone else decide."}, {'account_id': 29071, 'date': '2019-12-17 00:24:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

ok i understand. but still this fix does not **close bug**. oslo.conf should provide a way to lock CONF either explicitly or indirectly.... without that there will always exist some weird racings....'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-12-17 17:36:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

> ok i understand. but still this fix does not **close bug**.
 > oslo.conf should provide a way to lock CONF either explicitly or
 > indirectly.... without that there will always exist some weird
 > racings....

Except self._groups is a private member, so this isn't something consumers of oslo.config could or would do. I suppose if there were another place where we iterate on the groups internally this could be a problem, but I'm not sure where such a thing would be. The only other place I can think of where we do something similar is in the config generator, and that isn't a runtime thing so it doesn't have the concurrency problem.

If we find other places where we are iterating racy objects then we should certainly address them, but I'm not sure there's a need or reasonable way to lock the entire config object."}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-12-17 17:39:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

I'm ok to continue with this one due to the detailed commit msg instead of https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698892/

 > ok i understand. but still this fix does not **close bug**.
 > oslo.conf should provide a way to lock CONF either explicitly or
 > indirectly.... without that there will always exist some weird
 > racings....

I agree it can be worth to provide a lock CONF to completely avoid this kind of issue, however, I think this patch fix the bug related by https://launchpad.net/bugs/1856312, and so we can continue with the *Closes-Bug* tag, did you seen something else that we can consider to move the tag as a *Partial-Bug*?"}, {'account_id': 29071, 'date': '2019-12-18 00:51:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I'm ok to continue with this one due to the detailed commit msg
 > instead of https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698892/
 > 
 > > ok i understand. but still this fix does not **close bug**.
 > > oslo.conf should provide a way to lock CONF either explicitly or
 > > indirectly.... without that there will always exist some weird
 > > racings....
 > 
 > I agree it can be worth to provide a lock CONF to completely avoid
 > this kind of issue, however, I think this patch fix the bug related
 > by https://launchpad.net/bugs/1856312, and so we can continue with
 > the *Closes-Bug* tag, did you seen something else that we can
 > consider to move the tag as a *Partial-Bug*?

I feel more comfortable if this ps taged as partial bug. But I am afraid there is going to full of this kind of bug fixes if dynamically registering going to be a more preferable solution."}, {'account_id': 29071, 'date': '2019-12-18 00:52:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/train as commit 22c286c63b15b6f0acf6f696b98226a9257bf745'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-13 16:24:41.000000000', 'message': "Ensure option groups don't change during logging

oslo.config allows us to configure groups and options dynamically. This
can cause a race with our logging as we attempt to iterate through
option groups that are changing under our feet. This wouldn't be a huge
issue, since these are just logs are we can always log again, if needed,
but we store groups in a dictionary and Python doesn't like us changing
the size of a dict it's iterating through:

  RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during iteration

Given that we're only reading through this option group and don't need
to worry about a group _disappearing_, the solution is pretty simple:
create a copy of our option group names ahead of time so we don't need
to worry about new ones coming and messing things up.

No tests are included since this is a race and the only way I see to
reproduce this would involve lots of ugly threading.

Change-Id: Id3b28465d645a24f0fcebff2dd68a9bd30e21594
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1856312
"}]
commit_message:
Ensure option groups don't change during logging

oslo.config allows us to configure groups and options dynamically. This
can cause a race with our logging as we attempt to iterate through
option groups that are changing under our feet. This wouldn't be a huge
issue, since these are just logs are we can always log again, if needed,
but we store groups in a dictionary and Python doesn't like us changing
the size of a dict it's iterating through:

  RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during iteration

Given that we're only reading through this option group and don't need
to worry about a group _disappearing_, the solution is pretty simple:
create a copy of our option group names ahead of time so we don't need
to worry about new ones coming and messing things up.

No tests are included since this is a race and the only way I see to
reproduce this would involve lots of ugly threading.

Change-Id: Id3b28465d645a24f0fcebff2dd68a9bd30e21594
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1856312

commit_message:
zuul: all functional jobs now depend on linter job first

There is no need to run functional jobs if the linters don't pass; often
due to syntax errors.
This patch will help to save CI resources when syntax isn't good in a
patch.

Change-Id: I1a45fdc6c818e00cd97fef12dc608ee4550279cb
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
[ceph-client] force to set ceph-mgr module configs

This is to force setting the config values for all moduels since nautilus
version will not let us set them  before mgr starts.

Change-Id: I0e370b525b628fce040b33ab2e403b8b71e948cb

commit_message:
New Zuul v3 devstack-plugin-nfs-tempest-full job

This is meant to replace legacy-tempest-dsvm-full-devstack-plugin-nfs
in both cinder and nova.

Check the plugin against all the supported branches
(but ocata) to prevent regressions.

Change-Id: I86be2db18685f36fb3f67be03271608637c79151

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-18 11:12:57.000000000', 'message': 'Always source lib/apache when lib/tls is used

When tls-proxy is enabled, few functions in lib/tls relies on lib/apache
functions (restart_apache_server, stop_apache_server, enable_apache_site,
enable_apache_mod).
It is thus necessary to source lib/apache whenever lib/tls is used.

Change-Id: Ia9ffdc490d0cba04a084d572312e177b19791585
'}]
commit_message:
Always source lib/apache when lib/tls is used

When tls-proxy is enabled, few functions in lib/tls relies on lib/apache
functions (restart_apache_server, stop_apache_server, enable_apache_site,
enable_apache_mod).
It is thus necessary to source lib/apache whenever lib/tls is used.

Change-Id: Ia9ffdc490d0cba04a084d572312e177b19791585

commit_message:
Make nova_novncproxy use BUMPs

We have a lock of VNC version inside repo_packages [1]. We should
try using it as otherwise this may result in broken console

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/src/branch/stable/stein/playbooks/defaults/repo_packages/nova_consoles.yml#L33

Change-Id: Icd1fe43c9fa3ab16f9bdaf0a2cb60854c0e15e97
(cherry picked from commit 1de7b24e701bda75e0fc1d019510f71f16608502)

commit_message:
tripleo-keystone-resources: reduce permissions for clouds.yaml

0644 was too open, and it's problematic for security reasons.
Let's reduce to 0600; so only root can read and write the file.

Change-Id: Ic463aa66b719bfc8f860662e8387f3eea6faaf01

commit_message:
Stop supporting python2

We're peeling python2 from libraries now, so Stop running python2
versions of test jobs. Leaving removing the test jobs themselves
for the moment as they're still used in other repos.

Change-Id: Ic6d56e3636b757201d83649f075005ed3ae1e1a6

[{'created': '2019-12-17 14:21:02.000000000', 'message': "Create /var/log/journal directory during step-0

While I93dcc57aff63b91dab475b0c114b278324434e41 did the right thing, it
didn't do it in the right place.

This patch adds the creation without removing the misplaced code, so
that we can do an easy backport to Train.
A follow-up will be the actual revert of the other change.

Change-Id: Id937389e4eda5c1fc4634ab14695390a09300468
Closes-Bug: #1856278
"}]
commit_message:
Create /var/log/journal directory during step-0

While I93dcc57aff63b91dab475b0c114b278324434e41 did the right thing, it
didn't do it in the right place.

This patch adds the creation without removing the misplaced code, so
that we can do an easy backport to Train.
A follow-up will be the actual revert of the other change.

Change-Id: Id937389e4eda5c1fc4634ab14695390a09300468
Closes-Bug: #1856278

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2019-11-07 06:55:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Talking to the Docs people at the PTG, sounds like there is a CONTRIBUTING.rst in the cookie cutter repo that might be a good place to let the template live since there is already a place holder there. 

It could live in openstack-manuals, but then it would need to maintained in two places which never bodes well.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-11-07 11:03:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-11-12 03:11:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-11-13 06:41:17.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from project-contrib-docs-goal to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-11-13 06:45:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I am not sure if this should be a formal vote. We don't have a precedent yet for proposed goals, and I think the idea of the proposed goals was to iterate simply, for which documentation-change or goal-update would be a better match."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-11-13 06:58:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

(1 comment)

I agree on the idea, and it was well received during the forum.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-11-13 21:33:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

As discussed during the Forum, I agree that all of these things are valuable things to do. However, this does not meet my personal criterion for what should a community goal should be - namely, that community goals should be reserved for things that *every* project needs to do before we can get *any* value. Community goals are necessary to solve a co-ordination problem in such cases, but we should be respectful of contributors' time by not mandating work for them in other cases. We don't need to go looking for tasks to make projects do; people have plenty of work already. We *do* need to keep looking for ways to move OpenStack forward and not throw them in the 'too hard' basket just because they require changes in every project.

For tasks like this where individual projects benefit in proportion to the effort they are prepared to spend on it, we should allow them to prioritise it as they see fit. Of course if somebody wants to define standard formats for this documentation and help projects with implementing it, that's great!"}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-11-15 16:28:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

I find it quite difficult to make this very measurable, also, I worry that this becomes something that is hard to define in a specific way.

The way I think this can work is by defining perhaps some 'yaml' structure which we can store in repos that openstackdocstheme can leverage to generate these docs.

This can keep things consistent across all projects.  I would take an example to Thierry's work regarding different deployment tools and their capabilities."}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2019-11-18 19:57:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2019-11-18 20:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2019-11-18 20:05:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I find it quite difficult to make this very measurable, also, I
 > worry that this becomes something that is hard to define in a
 > specific way.
 > 
 > The way I think this can work is by defining perhaps some 'yaml'
 > structure which we can store in repos that openstackdocstheme can
 > leverage to generate these docs.
 > 
 > This can keep things consistent across all projects.  I would take
 > an example to Thierry's work regarding different deployment tools
 > and their capabilities.

I think with the template ( contributing.rst that will live in the cookie cutter repo) it should be doable. My view of completion is that each project (probably in the main repo) there is a contributing.rst file and it has all the fields in the template present/filled out. Do you think thats enough? 

I had also talked to the Docs folks at the PTG about maybe having a job that tests that the fields are there, but that kinda seems like overkill."}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2019-11-18 20:08:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> As discussed during the Forum, I agree that all of these things are
 > valuable things to do. However, this does not meet my personal
 > criterion for what should a community goal should be - namely, that
 > community goals should be reserved for things that *every* project
 > needs to do before we can get *any* value. Community goals are
 > necessary to solve a co-ordination problem in such cases, but we
 > should be respectful of contributors' time by not mandating work
 > for them in other cases. We don't need to go looking for tasks to
 > make projects do; people have plenty of work already. We *do* need
 > to keep looking for ways to move OpenStack forward and not throw
 > them in the 'too hard' basket just because they require changes in
 > every project.
 > 
 > For tasks like this where individual projects benefit in proportion
 > to the effort they are prepared to spend on it, we should allow
 > them to prioritise it as they see fit. Of course if somebody wants
 > to define standard formats for this documentation and help projects
 > with implementing it, that's great!

I totally understand and generally would agree, but I also think there are things that need to be done in all projects and would not happen without something unifying and driving work like being a goal."}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2019-11-18 20:08:47.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from project-contrib-docs-goal to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-11-19 08:59:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

I consider it a positive improvement for OpenStack.'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-11-19 17:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-11-20 17:41:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote-1

(3 comments)

I am +1 on accepting this as goal (being First contact SIG member where it can help a lot).

But we need to finalize the templates first to be consistent across projects. Few fields can vary especially in PTL guide which we can make optional.'}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2019-11-20 18:12:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

Looks good to me.  Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-11-21 10:54:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1 Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I agree with Ghanshyam that the patch moving proposed goal to selected goal should be separate, hence my CodeReview-1.

I think having minimal contributor documentation is a valuable goal, and as Kim mentioned in the session, there is value for some consistency across all official openstack project teams there. So Rollcall-Vote+1.'}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2019-11-26 01:13:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2019-11-26 01:18:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2019-11-26 01:31:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-11-26 09:41:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-11-26 14:55:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1

I think what matters is that it's consistent too. 

I like the concept, let's see how it's implemented in the details."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-11-26 14:55:48.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from project-contrib-docs-goal to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-11-26 16:10:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Fix pep8 errors found by hacking 2.0.0

The new hacking release found some pep8 errors, fix them.
Unfortunately, moving to 2.0.0 pulled a thread with other
dependencies causing issues, so for now pin it below
1.2.0 to get the gate functioning again.

Change-Id: Ic8ee670e03dde0669231477a4209b01eb8fba7fd

commit_message:
HA: enable cluster-common-tag naming scheme by default

Since Id369154d147cd5cf0a6f997bf806084fc7580e01, HA services
can now be configured to use a floating container image name
"cluster-common-tag/<servicename>:pcmklatest" to allow
minor update to a new image without service disruption, even
when the namespace changes in the image URI configured in Heat.

Enable that new naming scheme by default for pacemaker deployments.

Closes-Bug: #1854730

to allow minor update to arbitrary use container image name whose

Change-Id: I7a63e8e2d9457c5025f3d70aeed6922e24958049

[{'created': '2019-04-25 09:49:48.000000000', 'message': 'Use upper constraints from opendev.org

oslo.cache uses a simple curl command in its tox_install.sh
to fetch the upper-constraints, and curl does not follow redirects
that are now in place due to move to opendev.org.

This breaks running tox-based tests w/o overriding the
UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE which upstream CI does,
for example running tox locally.

Change-Id: Ifcb555c8f4ccb813b48c613c79dceb4bf23318eb
(cherry picked from commit 6eceb160eaaebbc6ea04768f62876738aa61c2d1)
'}]
commit_message:
Use upper constraints from opendev.org

oslo.cache uses a simple curl command in its tox_install.sh
to fetch the upper-constraints, and curl does not follow redirects
that are now in place due to move to opendev.org.

This breaks running tox-based tests w/o overriding the
UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE which upstream CI does,
for example running tox locally.

Change-Id: Ifcb555c8f4ccb813b48c613c79dceb4bf23318eb
(cherry picked from commit 6eceb160eaaebbc6ea04768f62876738aa61c2d1)

[{'created': '2019-11-21 20:14:24.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Ceph Nautilus compatibility

This change updates the Ceph charts to use Ceph Nautilus images
build on Ubuntu Bionic instead of Xenial. The mirror that hosts
Ceph packages only provides Nautilus packages for Bionic at
present, so this is necessary for Nautilus deployment.

There are also several configuration and scripting changes
included to provide compatibility with Ceph Nautilus. Most of
these simply allow existing logic to execute for Nautilus
deployments, but some logical changes are required to support
Nautilus as well.

Change-Id: Id2d9d7b35d4dc66e93a0aacc9ea514e85ae13467

commit_message:
Ceph Nautilus compatibility

This change updates the Ceph charts to use Ceph Nautilus images
built on Ubuntu Bionic instead of Xenial. The mirror that hosts
Ceph packages only provides Nautilus packages for Bionic at
present, so this is necessary for Nautilus deployment.

There are also several configuration and scripting changes
included to provide compatibility with Ceph Nautilus. Most of
these simply allow existing logic to execute for Nautilus
deployments, but some logical changes are required to support
Nautilus as well.

NOTE: The cephfs test has been disabled because it was failing
the gate. This test has passed in multiple dev environments, and
since cephfs isn't used by any openstack-helm-infra components we
don't want this to block getting this change merged. The gate
issue will be investigated and addressed in a subsequent patch
set.

Change-Id: Id2d9d7b35d4dc66e93a0aacc9ea514e85ae13467

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-17 18:45:19.000000000', 'message': 'Reduce osh-infra-logging job scope

This updates the osh-infra-logging single node job to omit the
fluentbit deployment step, as having multiple logging daemonsets
deployed to the single node jobs is causing IO issues. Also, it
was noted that the fluentd-deployment step was missing the
overrides to move the fluentd-deployment release from utilizing a
daemonset to a deployment. This resulted in 3 logging daemons
being deployed to a single host

Change-Id: I4a0c5550e6ea6a331aab0082a975f161e65704bf
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Reduce osh-infra-logging job scope

This updates the osh-infra-logging single node job to omit the
fluentbit deployment step, as having multiple logging daemonsets
deployed to the single node jobs is causing IO issues. Also, it
was noted that the fluentd-deployment step was missing the
overrides to move the fluentd-deployment release from utilizing a
daemonset to a deployment. This resulted in 3 logging daemons
being deployed to a single host

Change-Id: I4a0c5550e6ea6a331aab0082a975f161e65704bf
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

commit_message:
Add support to configure pcsd bind address

Add support to configure pcsd bind address so that we can
make pcsd listen on specific address instead of all interfaces
on the node.

Related-Bug: #1856626
Change-Id: I14d44d983259b4b9fb56173a8d538b3400644805

recheck'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2019-10-08 09:20:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

Tried to analyze why "test_create_delete_vnf_with_placement_policy_affinity" test is failing. It's working fine in my dev. environment.

I'm not able to check the logs [1] from CI job as it's not available. But looking at the code, it seems that heat-engine is not able to get the stack running in "CREATE_COMPLETE" status due to which tacker couldn't change the status from "PENDING_CREATE" to "ACTIVE. Hence it's failing with assertion error "PENDING_CREATE" != "ACTIVE".

There could be several reasons why heat is not able to bring stack status to "CREATE_COMPLETE". One of which could be nova due to "No valid host" to run the VDU or it's taking more than 300 seconds (constants.VNF_CIRROS_CREATE_TIMEOUT) to bring the VNF status to "ACTIVE".

[1] : https://0713711d830e78d2eaf6-ce557708b87a3b26463b6947241b4c8b.ssl.cf1.rackcdn.com/642746/19/check/tacker-functional-devstack-multinode/dba9cc6/controller/logs/'}, {'account_id': 18955, 'date': '2019-11-20 12:31:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Patch Set 19 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 18955, 'date': '2019-12-16 11:35:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: Patch Set 20 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 18955, 'date': '2019-12-17 20:07:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: Patch Set 21 was rebased'}]

commit_message:
[fix] Allow cluster OS upgrade without specifying kube_tag

If kube_tag is not specified in the new cluster_template, the existing
kube_tag should be reused. At the moment, we simply see this error which
does not make any sense:

    $ openstack coe cluster upgrade k8s k8s-alt
    '\'kube_tag\'\n (HTTP 500) (Request-ID: req-652883e9-05f3-43f1-b94d-8c6e0de75a2e)

Story: 2005201
Task: 37712

Change-Id: Ic15ad96a13f18c820bba592d4550f3a4fa951ffb

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/674770/1 : FAILURE in 2h 15m 52s'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-08 13:54:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Clean backport for a low priority fix. This is fine but I probably wouldn't take this past rocky to queens."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-08 14:08:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

Actually once dansmith started looking at this he pointed out we're still calling the DB to load the group hosts for members of the group, which means this patch is just code cleanup, not really fixing a redundant DB call. I think the proper fix would have probably been to change to:

  group_hosts = group.hosts"}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2019-11-27 11:31:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

-1 given Matt's feedback here from Dan."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-17 21:08:42.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Let's just drop this."}]

commit_message:
Remove redundant group host setup

It seems that all the code path that ends up calling [1] goes through
[2] before so setting up group host at [1] is redundant.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/c7e9e667426a6d88d396a59cb40d30763a3265f9/nova/scheduler/utils.py#L944-L950
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/c7e9e667426a6d88d396a59cb40d30763a3265f9/nova/scheduler/utils.py#L996-L1000

Change-Id: I745aecb008f0867fcda2d3d2c7691621dd8f6168
Closes-Bug: #1788527
(cherry picked from commit f108d7967636ec1afceff0be386da15d70e2ca37)
(cherry picked from commit 0313d8143309157067aa85f7333d0d177a5b6609)

commit_message:
Adjust install path

The default COLLECTIONS_PATH is
~/.ansible/collections:/usr/share/ansible/collections. This change
updates the install directory to more closely matches where it needs to
be installed on the system path in order to be consumed.

Change-Id: Ifa786f33dc91895e07f64e4d8275e6a773207b86

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-28 03:10:22.000000000', 'message': 'Share snapshot image membership with instance owner

When an admin creates a snapshot of another project owners
instance, either via the createImage API directly, or via the
shelve or createBackup APIs, the admin project is the owner
of the image and the owner of the instance (in another project)
cannot "see" the image. This is a problem, for example, if an
admin shelves a tenant user's server and then the user tries to
unshelve the server because the user will not have access to
get the shelved snapshot image.

This change fixes the problem by leveraging the sharing feature [1]
in the v2 image API. When a snapshot is created where the request
context project_id does not match the owner of the instance project_id,
the instance owner project_id is granted sharing access to the image.
By default, this means the instance owner (tenant user) can get the
image directly via the image ID if they know it, but otherwise the image
is not listed for the user to avoid spamming their image listing. In the
case of unshelve, the end user does not need to know the image ID since
it is stored in the instance system_metadata. Regardless, the user could
accept the pending image membership if they want to see the snapshot
show up when listing available images.

Note that while the non-admin project has access to the snapshot
image, they cannot delete it. For example, if the user tries to
delete or unshelve a shelved offloaded server, nova will try to
delete the snapshot image which will fail and log a warning since
the user does not own the image (the admin does). However, the
delete/unshelve operations will not fail because the image cannot
be deleted, which is an acceptable trade-off.

Due to some very old legacy virt driver code which started in the
libvirt driver and was copied to several other drivers, several virt
drivers had to be modified to not overwrite the "visibility=shared"
image property by passing "is_public=False" when uploading the image
data. There was no point in the virt drivers setting is_public=False
since the API already controls that. It does mean, however, that
the bug fix is not really in effect until both the API and compute
service code has this fix.

A functional test is added which depends on tracking the owner/member
values in the _FakeImageService fixture. Impacted unit tests are
updated accordingly.

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/image/v2/index.html#sharing

Conflicts:
        nova/compute/api.py
        nova/compute/utils.py

NOTE(seyeongkim): The conflict is due to not having change

position.

commit_message:
Share snapshot image membership with instance owner

When an admin creates a snapshot of another project owners
instance, either via the createImage API directly, or via the
shelve or createBackup APIs, the admin project is the owner
of the image and the owner of the instance (in another project)
cannot "see" the image. This is a problem, for example, if an
admin shelves a tenant user's server and then the user tries to
unshelve the server because the user will not have access to
get the shelved snapshot image.

This change fixes the problem by leveraging the sharing feature [1]
in the v2 image API. When a snapshot is created where the request
context project_id does not match the owner of the instance project_id,
the instance owner project_id is granted sharing access to the image.
By default, this means the instance owner (tenant user) can get the
image directly via the image ID if they know it, but otherwise the image
is not listed for the user to avoid spamming their image listing. In the
case of unshelve, the end user does not need to know the image ID since
it is stored in the instance system_metadata. Regardless, the user could
accept the pending image membership if they want to see the snapshot
show up when listing available images.

Note that while the non-admin project has access to the snapshot
image, they cannot delete it. For example, if the user tries to
delete or unshelve a shelved offloaded server, nova will try to
delete the snapshot image which will fail and log a warning since
the user does not own the image (the admin does). However, the
delete/unshelve operations will not fail because the image cannot
be deleted, which is an acceptable trade-off.

Due to some very old legacy virt driver code which started in the
libvirt driver and was copied to several other drivers, several virt
drivers had to be modified to not overwrite the "visibility=shared"
image property by passing "is_public=False" when uploading the image
data. There was no point in the virt drivers setting is_public=False
since the API already controls that. It does mean, however, that
the bug fix is not really in effect until both the API and compute
service code has this fix.

A functional test is added which depends on tracking the owner/member
values in the _FakeImageService fixture. Impacted unit tests are
updated accordingly.

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/image/v2/index.html#sharing

Conflicts:
        nova/compute/api.py
        nova/compute/utils.py

NOTE(seyeongkim) The conflict is due to not having specific files in
queens.

Conflicts:
        nova/tests/unit/virt/powervm/test_image.py
        nova/tests/unit/virt/zvm/test_driver.py
        nova/virt/powervm/image.py
        nova/virt/zvm/driver.py

Change-Id: If53bc8fa8ab4a8a9072061af7afed53fc12c97a5
Closes-Bug: #1675791
(cherry picked from commit 6ca6f6fce691863901b01d37b8f6e3eadb2bcec4)

commit_message:
Add octavia-v2-dsvm-scenario-centos-8

This patch adds a new non-voting scenario job to test against CentOS 8
amphora images. Until CentOS 8 controllers are supported in Devstack,
this job runs Ubuntu controllers.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/697128/
Change-Id: Ia5cffced9d5af2de3a85b91be5358a15234f5e25

commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Iea3dba53b2363e164068091795d1824fcc156b92

recheck'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-12-17 16:46:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-12-17 16:46:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-10 15:32:24.000000000', 'message': 'HA: minor update of arbitrary container image name

HA services get their container image name from a pacemaker
resource configuration. This image name is shared between
all cluster nodes.

To achieve image update without service disruption, a pacemaker
resource is configured to use an intermediate image name
"<registry>/<namespace>/<servicename>:pcmklatest" pointing to
the real image name configured in Heat. This tag can then be
updated independently on every node during the minor update.

In order to support the same rolling update when the <namespace>
changes in the container image, we need a similar floating
approach for the prefix part of the container image.

Introduce a new Heat parameter ClusterCommonTag that, when enabled,
sets the intermediate image name to
"cluster-common-tag/<servicename>:pcmklatest". By default, this
parameter is disabled and the original naming scheme is conserved.

Note: by introducing this new naming scheme, we stop seeing a
meaningful image name prefix when doing a "pcs status", but since
we already can't tell what image ID the :pcmklatest tag points to,
we don't lose much information really.

Related-Bug: #1854730

Change-Id: Id369154d147cd5cf0a6f997bf806084fc7580e01
(cherry picked from commit a166ec6bcaae078a4f7ed91feb8e431fe031e0cb)
'}]
commit_message:
HA: minor update of arbitrary container image name

HA services get their container image name from a pacemaker
resource configuration. This image name is shared between
all cluster nodes.

To achieve image update without service disruption, a pacemaker
resource is configured to use an intermediate image name
"<registry>/<namespace>/<servicename>:pcmklatest" pointing to
the real image name configured in Heat. This tag can then be
updated independently on every node during the minor update.

In order to support the same rolling update when the <namespace>
changes in the container image, we need a similar floating
approach for the prefix part of the container image.

Introduce a new Heat parameter ClusterCommonTag that, when enabled,
sets the intermediate image name to
"cluster-common-tag/<servicename>:pcmklatest". By default, this
parameter is disabled and the original naming scheme is conserved.

Note: by introducing this new naming scheme, we stop seeing a
meaningful image name prefix when doing a "pcs status", but since
we already can't tell what image ID the :pcmklatest tag points to,
we don't lose much information really.

Related-Bug: #1854730

Change-Id: Id369154d147cd5cf0a6f997bf806084fc7580e01
(cherry picked from commit a166ec6bcaae078a4f7ed91feb8e431fe031e0cb)

commit_message:
Update: Run all roles update at once

Previously we ran role by role which is not necessary and not
intended way of production update. In case of proper testing on
preprod customers should run update as fast as possible which
means leveraging ability to run all roles at once and even all
nodes of selected roles at once. With this patch the Pacemaker
enabled roles will still update in serial but the roles will be
done in parallel. In case of 3 controller 3 database 3 messaging
setup it will look roughly like this:

Update of controller[0] database[0] messaging[0]
Update of controller[0] database[1] messaging[1]
Update of controller[1] database[2] messaging[2]
Update of controller[2]

This is due to not blocking between roles and each role taking
different amount of time to apply the update. At any moment the
pacemaker quorum is not broken.

Change-Id: Ib119210139886382726bc0ccddfdb4f7f6803015
(cherry picked from commit a2b433133de755c410d235172c0644173d17ae80)

commit_message:
Update: Ensure parallel execution

In middle of Queens and Rocky release we introduced option to
set parallel execution of minor update on selected role types.
If the environment went through FFWD or was deployed before this
option got backported we need to update the roles_data.

By default we have update_serial either unset at all for OSP13 and OSP14 or
we have it set where Pacemaker enabled nodes, CephOSD nodes and Networkers
have it set to 1. This is mostly defensive precaution and we do allow running
in parallel for CephOSD and Networkers for production systems that did enough
testing on preprod or can take small outage. We should also parallelize it in
CI as we just waste time here.

Change-Id: I4cff09dc6aa9ac944b20a52ae087a8923f55209f
(cherry picked from commit 2044957694d89eee9529d889859f0788767f7e28)
(cherry picked from commit ad0e9b3954a95eb19764ba7720a2649737119d49)

In a rare case like httpd reload by logrotate, heat-api returns
500 code. If this happens, trpleoclient can't get the status of
the stack even though the process is still on-going.

To handle this situation, tipleoclient should retry when it can't
get the stack information by 500 code.

Change-Id: I97a6825f4ff9f125eb597e5b7bd0c553c37e49e7

(cherry picked from commit 932fc6755a8315ccde2e90848ad3224f1fe16735)
"}]
commit_message:
Retry the connection to heat-api when 500 code

In a rare case like httpd reload by logrotate, heat-api returns
500 code. If this happens, trpleoclient can't get the status of
the stack even though the process is still on-going.

To handle this situation, tipleoclient should retry when it can't
get the stack information by 500 code.

Change-Id: I97a6825f4ff9f125eb597e5b7bd0c553c37e49e7
Closes-Bug: #1855633
(cherry picked from commit 932fc6755a8315ccde2e90848ad3224f1fe16735)

commit_message:
Support uploading image from data and stdin

It might be useful to upload image from stdin. Disadvantage is, that it
is not possible to calculate checksums and this will prohibit threaded
image upload when using swift and tasks.
Additionally fix checksum validation during image creation - when
create_image is not called through cloud layer - the result might be
different, when checksums of existing image match (due to call and
return cloud.get_image). Fixing this requires also completing image v1
(proper find). Yeah, lots of tests are affected by that change.

Required-by: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/650374
Change-Id: I709d8b48cb7867fd806e2f19781bb84739363843

commit_message:
Drop old neutron-grenade job

This job is still running python 2.7. As we are dropping py2 support in
Ussuri cycle, lets drop this job now.
There is same job called "grenade-py3" which runs on python 3 already
and this is still used in project's CI.

Change-Id: I4bc96e2b5d74e9dd2ad6c75136d84ae22c293218

commit_message:
Explicitly fail if trying to attach SR-IOV port

Attaching SR-IOV ports to existing instances is not supported
since the compute service does not perform any kind of PCI
device allocation, so we should fail fast with a clear error
if attempted. Note that the compute RPC API "attach_interface"
method is an RPC call from nova-api to nova-compute so the error
raised here will result in a 400 response to the user.

Blueprint sriov-interface-attach-detach would need to be
implemented to support this use case, and could arguably involve
a microversion to indicate when the feature was made available.

A related neutron docs patch https://review.openstack.org/695409
is posted for mentioning the limitation with SR-IOV port attach
as well.

Conflicts due to no having
Ifcc327f9f97e57d3d6f0db7045b56ffe60203eb9 and
I4440a19370da9807cc8c32b681542c7048c9977e in Pike.

[{'created': '2019-10-10 12:38:16.000000000', 'message': 'Error out interrupted builds

If the compute service is restarted while build requests are
executing the instance_claim or waiting for the COMPUTE_RESOURCE_SEMAPHORE
then those instances will be stuck forever in BUILDING state. If the instance
already finished instance_claim then instance.host is set and when the
compute restarts the instance is put to ERROR state.

This patch changes compute service startup to put instances into
ERROR state if they a) are in the BUILDING state, and b) have
allocations on the compute resource provider, but c) do not have
instance.host set to that compute.

commit_message:
Error out interrupted builds

If the compute service is restarted while build requests are
executing the instance_claim or waiting for the COMPUTE_RESOURCE_SEMAPHORE
then those instances will be stuck forever in BUILDING state. If the instance
already finished instance_claim then instance.host is set and when the
compute restarts the instance is put to ERROR state.

This patch changes compute service startup to put instances into
ERROR state if they a) are in the BUILDING state, and b) have
allocations on the compute resource provider, but c) do not have
instance.host set to that compute.

Change-Id: I856a3032c83fc2f605d8c9b6e5aa3bcfa415f96a
Closes-Bug: #1833581
(cherry picked from commit a1a735bc6efa40d8277c9fc5339f3b74f968b58e)
(cherry picked from commit 06fd7c730172190d7bf7d52bc9062eecba8d7d27)
(cherry picked from commit cb951cbcb246221e04a063cd7b5ae2e83ddfe6dd)
(cherry picked from commit 13bb7ed701121955ba015103c2e44429927e78d4)

[{'created': '2019-04-25 09:28:16.000000000', 'message': 'Use upper constraints from opendev.org

oslo.cache uses a simple curl command in its tox_install.sh
to fetch the upper-constraints, and curl does not follow redirects
that are now in place due to move to opendev.org.

This breaks running tox-based tests w/o overriding the
UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE which upstream CI does,
for example running tox locally.

Change-Id: I209a980f3345e037a7a9a1d9f89925e6eefa0c4e
(cherry picked from commit aee2164a3a91e120649e67301e8b365a4691770c)
'}]
commit_message:
Use upper constraints from opendev.org

oslo.cache uses a simple curl command in its tox_install.sh
to fetch the upper-constraints, and curl does not follow redirects
that are now in place due to move to opendev.org.

This breaks running tox-based tests w/o overriding the
UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE which upstream CI does,
for example running tox locally.

Change-Id: I209a980f3345e037a7a9a1d9f89925e6eefa0c4e
(cherry picked from commit aee2164a3a91e120649e67301e8b365a4691770c)

 > 
 > [1] https://bugs.python.org/issue29245

Right, bytes and unicode has created a lot of issues in py3 and this seems to be one of them.
Since this data is being written in file and not send/received from other APIs, i think unicode is the right format to follow.

Thanks for fixing this. LGTM.'}]

commit_message:
Fixed open tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile as text in Python3

Python3 opens tempfile by default as binary[1] and not as ascii,
and nvmetcli writes json output as ascii.

This issue was overlooked with Python2, since binary and ascii
variables are less distiguished there.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/tempfile.html
[2] https://bugs.python.org/issue29245

Change-Id: Ia1f280ab64f0dc90824d4cb9ed20a8537af32ef6
Closes-Bug: 1855855

commit_message:
Fix monasca-grafana being unbuildable due to old npm

Affected builds on Ubuntu which had:
npm 3.5.2
while the latest was:
npm 6.13.4
And CentOS had:
npm 5.6.0

This patch runs npm update via npm.
Pinned to 6.x.

Additionally, this moves npm packages prefix (root) to
/usr/local to avoid conflicts with native packages.

Change-Id: Ibaacc1cc478b2b2f8196a5da4eea3570d7d310ff
Closes-bug: #1856699

commit_message:
Remove log translations

Log messages are no longer being translated. This removes all use of
the _LE, _LI, and _LW translation markers to simplify logging and to
avoid confusion with new contributions.

See:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-i18n/2016-November/002574.html
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/113365.html
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages#Including_external_references
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/1674374

Change-Id: I4b188ee5b87b17f4e2a7f6a7a7d063d96269b33e

commit_message:
Use upper constraints from opendev.org

oslo.cache uses a simple curl command in its tox_install.sh
to fetch the upper-constraints, and curl does not follow redirects
that are now in place due to move to opendev.org.

This breaks running tox-based tests w/o overriding the
UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE which upstream CI does,
for example running tox locally.

Change-Id: Ifcb555c8f4ccb813b48c613c79dceb4bf23318eb
(cherry picked from commit 6eceb160eaaebbc6ea04768f62876738aa61c2d1)
